I played through Black Mesa last year before playing through this masterpiece, however I remember half life from my childhood as one of the first PC shooters i have ever seen. My older brother would play this game, but at the time I was a young kid and too afraid of the head crabs to play on my own. Let me start by saying this game is simply phenomenal. I was afraid that after playing Black Mesa I would be too turned off by the dated graphics from a game released in 1998 however, that was not the case. Black Mesa is incredible and the devs did phenomenal job re-creating half life, but I actually like this OG game better. Half Life is simply a classic. You know how they make you read timeless works of literature in school to appreciate what good writing is? That is what Half Life is to gaming. This game has had so much influence on the games we have played over the years that it deserves a play through for any FPS fan out there. I recently watched the documentary of how Half Life was developed and it only made me appreciate this even more. Definitely play this game and see what good games are actually made of. This is the product of people who care.

It's surprising how well this game holds up after 25 years.

Somehow I had never played the original Half-Life. I loved HL2 and its two Episodes, but I had never played HL. So I finally took the time to go back and play it, and it shocked me how well it stands the test of time. Obviously the graphics are outdated, just as so many other technological aspects of the game are, but from an overall gameplay perspective, it's still fun and it still feels good. 


But perhaps even more surprising is just how far ahead of its time this game was. So many modern FPS tropes came from here.

I've always loved 2004's Doom 3 because of how innovative and inventive the game was, but after playing Half-Life, my admiration for Doom 3 has ticked down a tad because I now see that so many of the ideas that I thought originated there were actually born 6 years earlier in Half-Life. So many of the segments and story beats and level types came straight out of Half-Life, just with more of a horror/ambiant feel added for Doom 3.

The only thing that actually feels dated to me (besides the visuals) in Half-Life, is the ladder climbing. The way ladders work is loose and annoying to navigate, as it's easy to come at them on an angle and fall off the side, leading to annoying fall damage.
Also, the final boss was a major annoyance. The last few levels in general weren't great. But everything else holds up extremely well and more importantly, is fun to play. The same CANNOT be said of most other shooters from that era.

If I had played this game upon release in 1998, I'd easily give it a 90% or perhaps even a 95% review score. But I played it in December 2023, not 1998. And even 25 years later, I'm still giving it a 75%, which is incredibly impressive for such an old game.

Introduction:
Half-Life is a game that needs no introduction. It revolutionized the FPS genre, won over 50 GOTY awards and has retrospectively been viewed as one of the greatest video games of all time. Everyone in the gaming community already knows just how influential Half-Life was and still is, but I wanted to explain why via this review (and of course to gush about one of my favorite games ever made).

Review:
As I said before, Half-Life is revolutionary because of how different it was from other FPS games. While games like Doom and Quake were pure shooters, Half-Life's gameplay is more varied. Half-Life integrates combat and puzzles into a unified package, both of which are well-designed. There is also a huge variety of weapons and enemies that make each encounter feel distinct from the other. Each encounter requires you to think about how to defeat enemies, adding an extra layer of inginuity to an action-packed experience.

Not only is the gameplay amazing, but so is the overall presentation. Upon release, Half-Life's visuals were considered impressive for its detailed character animations and immersive environments. Even though Half-Life's visuals have certainly aged by modern standards, I still think they are impressive and carry a unique charm. The character designs, particularly the Xen creatures, are creative and the environments have so much attention to detail, already adding to Half-Life's immersive atmosphere.

Half-Life's narrative broke grounds for how games tell stories. Half-Life's plot is simple. A resonance cascade occurs, destroying the Black Mesa research facility, killing its scientists and it's up to Gordon Freeman to stop it. Pretty generic plot, isn't it? However, the way Half-Life told said story is incredible. For the entire game, the player's view never leaves Freeman's eyes and plot details are told through scripted events instead of cutscenes. I love this approach to narrative as I truly feel immersed into the game's world.

However, despite all of Half-Life's achievements, it's not without its flaws. There is one aspect of Half-Life that's bad, Xen. Half-Life's final few chapters take place in the alien borderworld of Xen. Xen's level design ranges from okay to awful. The seemless blend of combat and puzzles in the previous chapters is replaced by repetitive platforming. The enemy placement is cheap and the final boss is very easy once you know how to beat it. I dislike Xen; not only does it leave an amazing game on a sour note, but also wastes so much potential.

Final Verdict:
Despite a disappointing final act, Half-Life is amazing and also one of my favorite games of all time. The gameplay is unique, the visuals are charming and the way it tells its story is downright incredible. Half-Life is a masterpiece and one of the best titles in the FPS genre I've ever played, ever. I would recommend everyone who calls themselves a gamer to play Half-Life at least once.

This first series is a timeless masterpiece that revolutionized the gaming industry.  From its immersive storyline and charming characters to its innovative SCFI (alien and zombie) themed gameplay mechanics, Half-Life sets the standard for first-person shooters.  The game's innovative level design, coupled with the smooth development of the narrative, makes the story in this game very exciting and keeps players engaged from start to finish, there is a community that is still active today by creating various cool mods that are free to try, there are mods  things that are fun to use such as more modern graphics, co-op story mode, and others (keep in mind that mods are not to be misused in online games and protected servers or you will suffer the consequences).  Graphics like this for their time were truly amazing.  This game is more than just a game it is an experience every gamer should have.  Even decades after its release, the game continues to inspire and influence game developers around the world.  If you haven't played Half-Life, you're missing out on a true gaming gem.  Old but gold

While I understand this is a classic and one of the greatest games of its time which is why I decided to play this game in 2024 in the first place, I want to give people who are interested in playing this game like I was some idea of what its like to play this game now. I will start off with my major issue with this game, the controls. they feel like walking in a pool while the floor is covered with dish washer soap, you will be slipping all over the place and the slightest movement gives you uncontrollable momentum, and BTW, you will need to platform occasionally to progress further. Second issue is there is zero guidance other than what NPCs tell you to do, and if you miss it, you can't have them tell you what your objective is again, however, the game is linear and is straight forward but at times can just feel cryptic (will not give examples to avoid spoilers). There are some other minor issues but I don't want to be unfair to this game since it came out decades ago so to summarize, unless you don't mind getting stuck wondering what to do every now and then and you don't find awkward controls to be an issue then you might enjoy this game, but otherwise just watch a play through on you tube if you are interested in its story. This comment is meant to be for helpful purposes only and not a critique of a game that came out decades ago.

As I sit here reflecting on my journey through Half-Life, I can't help but feel an overwhelming sense of accomplishment. Twenty-six years after first laying my hands on this iconic game, I've finally conquered its challenges and emerged victorious. It's been a long road, filled with nostalgia, frustration, and ultimately, triumph.

I remember being just a kid of 8 or 9 when I first experienced the groundbreaking world of Half-Life. Even at that young age, I was captivated by its immersive storytelling and innovative gameplay mechanics. But, like many youngsters of the time, I struggled to progress beyond the initial levels. The game felt daunting, its puzzles perplexing, and its enemies formidable. Then, at age 10, I made another attempt, but still, the later stages proved too daunting for my inexperienced gaming skills.

But now, armed with years of gaming experience and a determination to revisit this classic, I embarked on my journey through Half-Life once more. As I navigated the intricate corridors of the Black Mesa Research Facility, I found myself rediscovering the awe and wonder that had captivated me all those years ago. The game's seamless integration of storytelling and gameplay kept me engaged at every turn, with scripted sequences seamlessly driving the plot forward without ever breaking the immersive first-person perspective.

The puzzles, which once seemed insurmountable, now presented welcome challenges that tested my problem-solving skills. Whether it was navigating a maze of conveyor belts or using environmental hazards to dispatch enemies, each puzzle felt like a satisfying victory once overcome. And the addition of the long jump module added a new dimension to the gameplay, requiring precise timing and skillful maneuvering to navigate the platformer-style jumping puzzles of Xen.

But perhaps the greatest challenge awaited me near the end of the game, as I faced off against the formidable Nihilanth. As I journeyed through the alien-infested landscapes of Xen, I could feel the tension building with each step closer to my final confrontation. The Nihilanth's lair was a sight to behold, a sprawling cavernous expanse that served as the backdrop for our epic showdown.

And what a showdown it was. The Nihilanth tested my skills like never before, with its devastating attacks and formidable defenses pushing me to the brink of defeat. But I refused to give up, drawing on every ounce of determination and skill I had acquired throughout my journey. And finally, after a grueling battle that seemed to stretch on for an eternity, I emerged victorious, the Nihilanth vanquished and the portal to Xen sealed once and for all.

As I watched the credits roll and the iconic theme music filled the air, I couldn't help but feel a sense of satisfaction wash over me. I had finally accomplished what seemed impossible all those years ago, and my inner child rejoiced at the triumphant conclusion of this epic adventure. Half-Life will always hold a special place in my heart, not just as a groundbreaking piece of gaming history, but as a timeless classic that has brought joy and inspiration to gamers of all ages.

It's kind of a given that this game SHOULD be played as it's essentially a history lesson in video game media. Does it hold up? In some ways it does, in some it doesn't.

Without speaking on the graphical side of things, which are already obvious (come on, the game is 25 years old), it is nice to notice bits and bobs from a technical perspective that give you that eureka moment of "so THEY did this first!". The whole world and storytelling, while not 'unseen' in today's landscape, still works very well. The game is eerie and creepy, as well as mysterious. 

Does the gameplay feel dated? Yes. Is there still some fun to be found? Sure. But if you find yourself playing new releases that keep coming out with bugs and all sorts of nonsense, I think it's better to just spend some pennies on sale and have yourself a nice history lesson.

If there is one thing I hate most in gaming, it is when a game overstays its welcome. Valve is exceptional at avoiding gameplay fatigue, and Half-Life is a prime example of that. In Half-Life, every mission is unique with its own mechanics and scenery, and never lingers in one place for too long. When one challenge is exhausted, a new one presents itself right around the corner, and this feeling never leaves until the credits roll. Although I have my issues with this game, mostly regarding the heavy dependence on save scumming and some janky physics, i believe it is unfair to criticize a game from 1998 for issues that any game from that era would have suffered from. I love this game, for its historical importance for gaming, and for the great experience that it still is today, which is why I have a very strong opinion that this is one of the best first person shooters that I have ever played!

Half-Life originally came out when I was in middle school, and though I remember buying it maybe a year or two later, that was only to play Counter-Strike. Remember those days when mods were full-fledged games, sometimes better than the game they were modded on? Common practice has become a rare circumstance now.

That said, I don't think I ever actually played it! In 1997, I rented FFVII and for a few years soaked up every JRPG I could find and had time to play. So, now in 2024, playing through Half-Life for the first time is a... challenge. I respect the absolute hell out of this game for what it did to the FPS genre and the larger impact it's had on narrative-driven games, but man... it's rough... Kudos must be given because I was able to run the original non-source version with little to no tweaking needed. Turn off the head-bob though; it's by far the most extreme case of it in any game I can think of.

Any visual media that's over two decades old will certainly show age, so you have to accept that. Visually, you see the limits pushed in some of these levels, especially some of the cliff-side ones. The character models, though few, do the job. But where the game does shine is the alien enemies. Lord, they did some good work on making nightmare fuel when they created these ones.

I think the No-Clip documentary on the creative process of Half-Life helps immensely to try and frame the release window around what it was like at the time. A fully connected game world was pretty much unheard of in 1998, and Half-Life succeeds in that quite well. If there weren't the chapter popups, then sometimes you wouldn't even realize you've started a new section. This is the big impact that Half-Life leaves on the gaming industry, narration through the character's eyes, in a complete package.

This game is freakin' HARD. I'm not kidding (or I'm bad, maybe a mix of both!) when I say that. I truly think there were more deaths than a Dark Souls playthrough. The combat is tight, but the human enemies must have five layers of kevlar on because they take a punch before they go down. There's a decent variety of weaponry, including alien and tech ones, and figuring out which to use versus which enemies is part of the puzzle.

Half-Life has a banger soundtrack, but sadly, we don't get enough of it!

Speaking of puzzles, the game features countless platforming sections that act as the puzzles found in this title. Most were self-explanatory after a bit of tooling around, but a couple are downright wicked. Even though I was frustrated with a few, it's nice to mix up the combat that becomes a bit mundane after killing your 100th headcrab, and they are paced fairly well, though the later third of the game features some REALLY annoying ones.

I think I'll dive into Blue Shift and Opposing Force before continuing with Half-Life 2. I'm giving HL1 a 4/5 but can see how this was a 10/10 game back in '98.

Look this game is a timeless classic, it still has so much in it in a game from 1998 that games STILL cannot match today in 2024, which is so sad seeing as we have all these fancy engines and these so called "Triple A" developers that give us these games that now cost us $70 and beyond. With that being said, the first three quarters of this game is amazing, it's a blast from beginning to that point, but when you get to Lambda is when this game becomes a shit show, infinite spawning enemies in a certain point in the labs making moving around annoying, A portal puzzle (before actual Portal was made which did It far superior.) that relies on trail and error meaning quicksave after quicksave. Xen... eugh don't even get me started about Xen, it slows to a crawl until the nice little difficulty spike, then the final boss. Do not let me lead you away from this game, because it really should be played by EVERYONE it's just one of those classic games, that one day in the future will hopefully be displayed in a museum along side Resident Evil 2 and Tekken 3. It's a fun time, and did I mention it's only $10 USD (and it goes on sale with its expansions very often)? kinda hard to say no to a game for that price that is amazing, Not to mention it's expansions are pretty solid too, Opposing Forces being the best one.

Half-Life is as classic as you can get

The game starts slow, with ride to the work through the Black Mesa facility, where we play as Gordon Freeman and just continue our work as theoretical physics scientist as usual, but in our procedure, we accidentally creates an apocalypse scenario, which we will witness the fallout off it.

The combat loop is tight and inherintly fast paced with methodology of "Run, Think, Shoot and Live" through encounter to encounter. Fighting against aliens and against soldiers is exhilarating; two different factions with two different strategies that you need to approach accordingly.

The pacing of the campain, or at least the overworld section, is one of the best made. Escaping the failing facility through it's different sectors, finding survivors and discovering more and more about the facility we worked with. Activating last resort prevention of alien invasion and surviving the warzone to get to the Lambda facility is some of the best sections of the game.

Some of the best shooting campaings next to Half Life 2, Doom Eternal and Titanfall 2 and would have been perfect if not for the Xen chapters.

Xen feels like an afterthought in otherwise easiest 10/10 shooting experience possible I could give. Confusing layout, pacing halts to the snail's pace - especially in Interlopers chapter, complete lack of any resources to survive anything except from some random dead scientists' stash, drab color scheme reminding me of various color of vomit and textures of vein holes, which might have awakened Trypophobia in some of people.
Imagine if there was an alternative game where Xen was not bad...

Regardless, it is still worth playing, at least until the Xen starts.

Half-Life is, of course, one of the grand-daddies of the FPS genre, which revitalized the genre with relatively (for the time) sophisticated story-telling, made all the more immersive by involving the characters in the “cut-scenes”, i.e. You as player are seeing the exposition happen to you and around you as the game proceeds.  You play as Gordon Freeman, a physicist who....well, I think anyone who hasn't been living in a cave in the wilds of Mongolia knows what happens next.  By the way, some people kvetch about Xen, but I'm going to go against the grain and say that I have never had a problem with the level set.  So there.

Valve has recently released a souped up version of the game for its 30th anniversary, with modern graphics options, bug fixes, and more.

Positives:

-Gameplay-  While it may drag a little in some sequences, this is pretty much the pinnacle of FPS shooting and story-telling, with enemy AI that is still remarkable, and an incredibly diverse cast of monstrous and human opposition as well as supporting cast.  Awesome gun-play with a now sacrosanct group of weapons as well as a few surprises.

-Music/SFX-  Seminal and in many ways unsurpassed.

-Graphics/Textures/Models-  All right, so some of these look a little dated, but I'd still rather look around Black Mesa and Xen than some more modern, high-poly, graphics card melting environments.

Half=Life is the forefather of a lot of modern shooters spawning Counter Strike and the idea of using realistic weapons physics, and animations based on real world motion capture. To this day the game is well thought out, engaging, the story is fun and immersive. I'm having a blast replaying it again for my followers on Twitch Greydrak3. The story teaches you the basics of movement, cover, situational awareness and precision keyboard and mouse control. It's as much a tutorial for the 'in's and out's' of first person shooting as it is a challenge to play through to see how the story pans out.

It's a great retro game, and being a Gen-X gamer a fun one to hone my skills and just enjoy the fun story telling ride. We know there's an Area 51. Half=Life asks the question, what's in the other 50 areas? Black Mesa is a fun exploration of what exactly might be down in those D.U.M.B.s.

The graphics are blocky, but the controls are tight. A great way to warm up for other modern FPS.

This game is what helped put Steam on the map. It's worth checking out what all the hype was about.

[h1] Time To Save Humanity! [/h1] 
Half-Life is a series of first-person shooter (FPS) games developed and published by Valve. The games combine shooting combat, puzzles and storytelling. The original Half-Life, Valve's first product, was released in 1998 for Windows to critical and commercial success. Players control Gordon Freeman, a scientist who must survive an alien invasion.
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]

    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]The graphics were ahead of their time. As a game from 1998, this blows me away. Half-Life was a benchmark in terms of graphics and performance and it still shows. This game has obviously aged, but put me in a time machine to 1998 this game would make me speechless! Sharp graphics and a simple UI really makes this game stand out and still looks pleasant on the eye.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]I will say that the gameplay is amazing! It’s fast and smooth and aged pretty well for a 1998 title. The gunplay is really fun and you can use some really unique and fun weapons in this game. You can fight a ton of different enemies that require strategy and I love that difficulty. The atmosphere and environments are incredible and blows me away that this is a 1998 game. They did an amazing job in the gameplay/graphics section.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]Okay, well the story is pretty vague if i’m gonna be honest. I had many people recommend this game to me and told me that the story was a masterpiece, I must have been playing the wrong game. You don’t really get a mention of the antagonist. You just see him walk behind a wall or go through a portal. Not much screen time for the antonigist. All I knew was that you have to escape the lap and you end up facing the boss in the Xen (other world). The first half of the game was pretty good and I deeply enjoyed it. Once I got into that second half, my whole mood just switched. I did not like the second half, like at all. It was really repetitive and just boring. The other world was okay but didn’t bring my excitement back. It didn’t help that the last boss reminded me of the marshmallow dude from Ghostbusters. The story was a huge let down and maybe because I had high expectations (because everyone that told me about it hyped it up into oblivion).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]Half-Life has a great game length for the size. I beaten this game in like 13 hours, you may beat it faster because some sections were pretty tricky to pass. The replayability is not there in my opinion.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The sound design is not good. I get that it’s a game from 1998, but you can barely hear the voice actors in this game. If you have a lot of commotion in the background and they start talking, good luck on hearing them. The audio slider is so minimal as well. They don’t even have a dialogue or voice slider. Besides that the guns sound okay, and it’s what you expect from a game in 1998.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]Only issues I had was that I would get stuck in some environments (clipping issues) and sometimes if I got to a checkpoint, I would be stuck completely having to load an old save to get back to the checkpoint hoping not to get stuck again. It’s an old game so I’ll give it an excuse. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]The performance is great! I mean it’s an old game so we all should run this with no issues. It loads really fast and runs like butter. I had no stutters or freezes or even crashes so this game ages like fine wine in terms of compatibility and performance.[/td]

[h1] TLDR: 9.5/10 Happy 25th Birthday to one of the most creative, innovative, and standard-setting shooters of all time. Half-Life continues to never let it's age catch up to it. [/h1]

[b] Actual Review (No Spoilers): [/b] It's impossible to summarize this game in any way that it deserves. Half-Life was, and still is an amazing masterpiece. Almost every little detail of this game just works. The gameplay is satisfying, the story is seamless, and the immersion and worldbuilding are excellent. HL1 is one of those games that just continue to stand the test of time even all these years later.

HL1 is pretty much the complete package. You have a creative selection of weapons, used against unique enemies, all the while being rewarded for exploration as you scavenge for supplies and push forward through an interesting, environment-driven storyline. The (at the time) unparalleled level of immersion really helps you sink into the role of Gordon, and it still holds up if not exceeds the immersion in most games today.

Now unfortunately as steam and the goldsrc engine continually get updates, HL1 has slowly gotten a tad buggy. Most of the time it's small things like a lighting error here, some z-fighting textures there. But some things such as the sound engine sometimes breaks as well. The 25th anniversary update brought some patches, but there are also a whole host of mods and alternate versions of the game that help stabilize it. Would highly recommend looking into some bug fix mods if you're going to play HL1 for the first time.

That's really all I can say at this point. Half-Life has already been praised to death and rightfully so. If there is one shooter that all gamers need to play, It's without a doubt Half-Life. 9.5/10

More than 25 years after its original release and this game still rocks! 

The art style ensures that its graphics, despite being dated, are still generally pleasurable to behold and interact with. The game especially benefits from a good “impact” system where the damage you inflict on your enemies and environment, and which is inflicted on you, gives such a great response that it feels fun hitting things. Destroying things. Opening things. So on. 
(The relatively low record I have in this game on Steam is simply because I have mostly played it using an actual CD from 1998 and only recently started playing it via Steam) 

It speaks volumes that the game essentially still looks so good and feels so good after all these years – and that it still has a thriving modding community that shares the love for the game that it deserves. 

It is by no means perfect and some weapons feel much more fun to use than others. Some of the levels rank among my favourite levels of any game I have played, while other levels are boring or can, for other reasons, be found lacking. 

Overall, I know that the modern audience may not fall in love with this game the same way I have. Some will find it too outdated in terms of both graphics and gameplay. However, I do believe that it holds up so incredibly well that I can recommend it to a younger audience, who should be able to use the 2-hour Steam window to give the game a proper chance and not risk losing a few euros on a game they won’t enjoy.

Classic

Half-Life, stands as a timeless classic that has left an indelible mark on the gaming industry. From its innovative storytelling to groundbreaking gameplay mechanics, this first-person shooter remains a benchmark for excellence in the medium.

One of the standout features of Half-Life is its narrative delivery. Unlike many games of its time, Half-Life seamlessly integrates its gripping storyline into the gameplay without resorting to cutscenes. Players assume the role of Gordon Freeman, a scientist caught in a catastrophic experiment gone wrong at the Black Mesa Research Facility. The lack of traditional cutscenes allows for an immersive experience, as the narrative unfolds in real-time, creating a sense of urgency and connection with the protagonist.

The game's setting and atmosphere are expertly crafted, contributing to an unforgettable gaming experience. The desolate corridors of Black Mesa, coupled with the mysterious extraterrestrial threats, create a palpable sense of tension and suspense. Half-Life's world-building is second to none, with attention to detail that elevates the overall immersion. The use of scripted events and environmental storytelling adds layers of depth to the narrative, making it a truly engaging journey from start to finish.

Half-Life also revolutionized the first-person shooter genre with its innovative approach to gameplay. The introduction of the HEV Suit not only provided Gordon Freeman with protective gear but also served as an ingenious means of delivering power-ups. The game's puzzles and combat scenarios are meticulously designed, encouraging players to think strategically and adapt to diverse challenges. The inclusion of physics-based puzzles was groundbreaking at the time and showcased Valve's commitment to pushing the boundaries of interactive entertainment.

The AI of the enemies and allies in Half-Life further enhanced the gameplay experience. The Xen creatures and the military personnel, demonstrated advanced behaviors, creating dynamic and unpredictable encounters. This level of sophistication in AI was unprecedented in the late '90s and added an extra layer of realism to the gaming world.

Graphically, Half-Life was ahead of its time, boasting impressive visuals that contributed to the overall immersion. The game's design choices, from the iconic Hazardous Environment Suit to the alien landscapes of Xen, remain memorable to this day. The audio design is equally commendable, with a haunting soundtrack and atmospheric sound effects that heighten the sense of tension and excitement.

In conclusion, Half-Life is a pioneering masterpiece that not only redefined the first-person shooter genre but also set new standards for storytelling and immersion in video games. Its impact is still felt in the industry, and the game continues to be celebrated by players and developers alike.

Half-Life 1 to pierwsza odsłona serii, w której wcielamy się w postać Gordona Freemana, naukowca pracującego w tajemniczym laboratorium Black Mesa. Wszystko zaczyna się od nieudanego eksperymentu, który otwiera portal do innego wymiaru i wywołuje inwazję obcych stworzeń.

Fabuła jest niesamowicie wciągająca i pełna tajemnic. Musimy przemierzać różne lokacje, walczyć z przeciwnikami i rozwiązywać zagadki, aby przetrwać i odkryć, co tak naprawdę się stało. Historia jest świetnie skonstruowana i utrzymuje nas w napięciu przez całą grę.

Grafika w Half-Life 1 była rewolucyjna jak na swoje czasy. Chociaż teraz może wydawać się trochę przestarzała, to wciąż ma swój urok. Świat gry jest pełen szczegółów i atmosfery, a efekty specjalne są imponujące.

Half-Life 1 to kultowa gra, która zasługuje na swoje miejsce w historii gier komputerowych. Jeśli jesteś fanem FPS-ów i chcesz poznać korzenie tej serii, to koniecznie musisz zagrać w Half-Life 1. Będziesz miał niesamowitą przygodę!

Despite its age, Half-Life is still stands as a classic that anyone interested in FPS games should experience at least once. While its graphics and parts of its gameplay are indeed dated, Half-Life still excels in its setting, atmosphere, and story, all of which come together to create a game that might not be the best in one specific category, but ends up creating something that deserves its status as one of the best games ever made.

The main draw of Half-Life is the setting of Black Mesa itself, with varied environments from offices to labs to industrial processing areas. It helps add to the various set pieces of Half-Life, so that when one gets tired of a theme or environment, it's usually not long before things change and the game rejuvenates one's interest again.

The combat and AI are also incredibly well done for their time. While enemy behavior does seem simple nowadays, that doesn't make the gunplay not fun, especially with the various weapons one gets access to throughout the game. The variety of weapons combined with the different enemy types that necessitate varied tactics also keeps the game fresh. The controls and movement can feel slippery at times compared to more modern games or even Half-Life's sequels, but these are only minor nitpicks that one can quickly get used to.

In the end, there's not much to say against Half-Life, other than how its mechanics have been used and improved upon by so many other future games that it seems dated. Even then, various mods like MMod can modernize the game and make it fun to replay. For those looking for a classic experience, the 25th anniversary update also makes it a perfect time to play the game, now that it has some of its features updated and modernized, like fixes to widescreen, rescaled HUD elements, and new content like the Half-Life: Uplink demo. Half-Life is the game that started it all for Valve, and now is as good a time as any to experience what this classic has to offer.

We have a good one here folks. Half Life was valve's debut title, but this is no rushed, poorly made, mess of a game, no, not at all. Half Life is one of the most revolutionary and fun shooters that I have played in a good while, and while it's graphics are dated, I still recommend it over Black Mesa because of the map layouts feeling better with more comfortable enemy AI. This game is so good in fact, that a twitch series parodying this game blew up and now my profile pic is from that series. While that series uses Half Life: Source, I do not recommend that version since HL: Source was clearly rushed with many bugs and glitches. Overall, it takes a while to get used to this game, but when you do, it feels like an adrenaline rush of an adventure. Now before I go, I do want to mention the combat in this game. The combat in Half Life feels great, but not everybody will like it. The combat in Half Life uses strategy- wait, wait stop, stop walking away.
When I say strategic, I mean that the combat has you revisiting encounters to see what works and what doesn't, and while it sounds boring, it's what makes the game shine. The combat in Half Life is better than any other fps I've played with it's over powered, but low ammo weapons like the "Tas Cannon" and "Gluon Gun", to the more simple weapons, like a machine gun that also fires grenades, or an alien that you shove your hand into, which makes you able to shoot smaller aliens that are like little homing missiles. This game is crazy, and while people poop on the ending area, Xen, I got past it pretty quick, and while it was boring at times in Xen, the rest of the game was one of the best fps games I have ever played.
I absolutely recommend this game, and it's only $10, but wait for the summer sale, so you can get the half life complete bundle for about $17 or less. Half Life Complete includes: (Half Life, Half Life: Source, Half Life: Blue Shift, Half Life: Opposing Force, Half Life Deathmatch, HL: Deathmatch Source, Half Life 2, HL2: Episode 1&2, etc.)

Half-Life

One of the most iconic franchises of all time. So iconic, in fact, that a fucking crowbar, immediately makes people think of one face. Gordon Freeman
A game that has influenced the entire FPS genre as a whole. Honestly the first to bring narrative experiences to shooters. And having more strategic gameplay. The story is told in such a unique way, that you honestly don't see too often in games anymore. Through a little something called “Environmental Storytelling”
This quality of storytelling and worldbuilding starts as early as the game's tutorial. In my personal opinion, I feel like you can tell a LOT about a game looking at just its tutorial level. I love it when games explain mechanics via world building. It really sells the universe that much more. (Leagues better than a menu pop-up if you ask me) The tutorial is where I realized how special this game's immersion was (and still is to this day) friendly NPCs do not take very kindly to being provoked, as ones with guns will shoot at you if attacked.
 The biggest thing that blew me away in the original Half-Life (and all other future VALVe titles for that matter) The entire game is chock-full of interteractable objects, NPC reactions, that make this world feel so much more believable 25 YEARS after initial release. Usually, if I asked a question, the answer was yes! 
Environments that are THIS interactable aren’t as standard or common as you might think nowadays. Half-life was made during the era of video games being made up of 5 triangles, so to sell immersion, developers had to focus more on world interactivity and logic. The beginning section ALONE was just fun to walk around and explore. 
Another thing that helps with immersion is that through the entire game, you are always in control. No matter what. If there is dialogue or a set piece, it never rips control away from you like many games tend to do. In Half-Life, the story is told IN the world, and NOT in your face through boring cutscenes. Truth be told, there is only ONE “cinematic” in the entire game that rips control away from you. (When you get jumped and stripped of all of your weapons)
In a world where games nowadays are becoming more and more like interactable movies, this was an immense sense of fresh air. Half-Life makes you feel like a real person in this world. Not just a story vessel for fanfiction writers to show off their fetishes. Y’know it's pretty funny giving praises to a game that only have like what, 5 friendly NPC models to tell it? 
Somehow it just all WORKS. Having story delivered to you via only dialogue through the characters that you find, (Or the facilities announcement system) further just adds to the immersion factor.  Also the fact that Gordon does not say a SINGLE word throughout the entire franchise is so nice. Gordon being a silent protagonist makes every thought the player has, and every reaction so personal to you. Finally, I just HAVE to mention the G-Man. Look, I (nor anyone else for that matter) know too much about him, because you really only talk to him once in this entire game. (Guess you will have to play the rest of the series to find out!)
	But this beautiful storytelling and world building means absolutely nothing if the gameplay sucks. (theoretically) because in actuality, the gameplay of the original Half-Life fucking RULES. Half-Life (at the time) was at the cutting-edge of FPS gunplay. It’s so good, in fact, that 25 years after its initial release, it is still an absolute BLAST to play. The guns are all unique, punchy, and sound AMAZING to use.
Almost every weapon also has an alternate function (by pressing right click instead of left) which is pretty cool! The SMG, for example, launches an impact grenade, which is a 1 hit kill for a variety of enemies. For the Shotgun, it fires two shells instead of one.  (but it has a longer pump time) The Tau Cannon, it can charge for a more devastating blast. 
Many different alien races have come through the portal that know nothing about earth. Luckily for them, Gordon Freeman (and by extension the player) is an EXPERT when it comes to teaching them our ways (of violence). I like to think that Miyazaki (The creator of Dark Souls) was a HUGE Half-Life fan. I say this because there are so many bullshit surprise enemy attacks, (or just enemies appearing behind you for no apparent reason) so just watch out for that. 
Not saying that this is a negative, because in most situations I find it quite funny. I will say though that I played this on Hard difficulty. Half-Life does not take “Hard” lightly. I think I played a vast majority of the game below 10HP. Half-Life even has a follow system for the NPC’s, so you can have them follow you and “help” with combat, give you health if they are a scientist (welcome in my book considering I was almost always on the brink of death) or other very helpful things (like disarming trip mines) 
The overall sandbox of the game is also rolled out to you at a very nice pace. And tends to work really well with the flow of the story (Like how the crossbow, the only weapon that can shoot underwater, is introduced at the same time the gigantic man eating fish is) By far one of, if not my most favorite aspect of the original Half-Life (and the rest of the series for that matter) is the level design (in most cases anyway) 
Every single environment just feels so real and believable. The entire experience to me never felt like just a video game level. What I mean by this is that some games use very obvious signs or markings telling you where to go. Half-Life has nearly none of that. There is essentially zero hand-holding in this game. And like I mentioned earlier, Gordon will not say a SINGLE WORD during the length of his screen time. 
After playing, I can now truly understand why Half-Life is in the top 10 video games for most people (where it has taken a spot in my personal list as well) I'm blown away that this game holds up so well to this day, and that the gaming industry hasn’t changed all that much. In terms of mechanics anyway. Sure, games have gotten prettier, But in some areas I am willing to argue that it has in fact regressed in that field. 
Half-Life is still more mechanically sound than most games today. VALVe has always known how to make a timeless videogame (as their track record proves) Critic review scores on Half-Life should let you know that these guys have always been KING since 1998 (well almost always, in the case Artifact anyway) If you like video games, even slightly, you NEED to play Half-Life. And if the old graphics bug you that much, then just go play Black Mesa, the officially licensed 2015 remake of Half-Life. You have no excuses. 
Now go do yourself a favor and become enlightened. Or don’t. But then you would be missing out on quite a lot. I give Half-Life a solid 4.5 stars. Falls short in some spots but overall is one of the best and most tailored videogame experiences to date, even 25 years after release.

Half-Life je jedna z nejikoničtějších her v historii videoherního průmyslu a recenze na ni se tomuto faktu obvykle nevyhýbají.

Hra Half-Life byla původně vydána v roce 1998 společností Valve Corporation a od té doby získala obrovskou popularitu mezi hráči po celém světě. Kromě toho, že si získala srdce hráčů svou inovativní a příběhově bohatou hratelností, také ovlivnila způsob, jakým by se měly vytvářet herní příběhy a jak by měla vypadat moderní akční hra.

Jedním z nejvýznamnějších prvků Half-Life je jeho poutavý a napínavý příběh. Hráč přebírá roli Gordona Freemana, fyzika v Black Mesa Research Facility, která utrpí katastrofu, s níž se musí postavit tváří v tvář invazi mimozemských bytostí. Příběh je vyprávěn prostřednictvím očima hráče a je neuvěřitelně realistický a dojemný, což přidává na jeho síle a hráči se s ním rychle sžijí.

Grafika v Half-Life je na tehdejší dobu poměrně pokroková a stále drží poměrně dobře i dnes. Oceňuje se především kvalita textur a efektů, které jsou vysoké a zaručují realističnost herního světa. Na druhou stranu by mohla být dnes považována za zastaralou ve srovnání s moderními hrami, ale to nevadí, protože Half-Life byla vydána před více než dvaceti lety a grafika nebyla tehdy hlavním zaměřením.

Hratelnost Half-Life je také výjimečná. Hráč má možnost používat širokou škálu zbraní a vybavení a soupeřit s nepřátelskými silami, které jsou velmi inteligentní a náročné na zabití. Level design je propracovaný a nabízí různé strategické přístupy k překonání překážek. Přidává to do hry ještě větší rozměr a zvyšuje zájem hráče.

Celkově vzato je Half-Life jednou z nejlepších her v historii, ať už se zaměříme na její revoluční příběh, grafiku nebo hratelnost. Je to hra, kterou by si neměl nechat ujít žádný opravdový fanoušek videoher a která bude stále považována za průlomové dílo ve svém žánru.

Overall, I think I rate it a high 6/10. 

The gun-play is super fun. I can imagine gamers in the 90s spent hundreds of hours in this playing multiplayer. The puzzles are interesting and the difficulty level is just right for the most part, but you can excuse the game designers for making the bits where you fight a tank harder than usual. Plus, the ability to save at literally any time renders any complaints about the autosave null and void. Do not be afraid to save constantly when things get difficult. The movement, especially at the beginning, can feel like the entire game is an ice-level, but you kind-of get used to it by the end. It helps you feel more badass as you glide around the level shooting soldiers and aliens. You will fall off some ledges though.

My biggest issues with this is its...presentation. The graphics are an unavoidable result of its time and it does take away from the experience a bit. The story wasn't anything particularly mind-blowing. It just doesn't meet the expectations I had from half-life fans being obsessed with getting a third game. I'm guessing that's because Half-life 2 is the masterpiece and this is a flawed but still fun lead up to that. Most of the time I could barely hear what the NPCs were saying. Some high ranking enemies felt way too strong for how easily you lose your health and they don't really react to being shot until their dead. 

The design of the aliens was really cool and The soundtrack is awesome (if you put mp3 volume at max). The weapons  were pleasantly varied, though some I barely used at all (trip mines). FYI, the tutorial is a separate level that you access from the main menu. Play through it. You'll learn how to crouch jump and long jump, things that are essential for finishing this game. Seriously.

I avoided Half-Life for a long time.  I knew about it and I knew how beloved it was, but it didn't seem like something I'd enjoy.  For a very long time, my only real exposure to the series was (of all things) the ridiculous video series "Half-Life Full Life Consequences", and while I loved the Portal games Half-Life seemed to be a completely different beast.  More serious, more violent.  It looked on the surface like something for "hardcore" gamers.  It wasn't until I watched HLVRAI (An improv comedy series taking place in a Garry's Mod VR version of the game) and saw people actually move through the HL world that I started to be intrigued by the game itself and its odd lore, and decided to finally give it a shot.  I've played it through twice now, once on PS2 and once here on Steam.  While I loved the game both times the Steam version was by far the better experience (although I missed the option to replay as a Vortigaunt in this one).  I'm sure I'll be revisiting it in the future.

The biggest thing I realized when I finally got around to playing is that Half-Life is just as weird as Portal; it just doesn't have a wise-cracking malevolent AI to rub that fact in your face.  Black Mesa is just as messed up as Aperture Science, and Gordon Freeman isn't exactly a heroic protagonist.  Depending on how you play, he can range from "guy who comes in late to work, helps to conduct a dangerous experiment despite the risks, and has to deal with the consequences," to "silent agent of chaos", to "remorseless serial murderer."  Everything, including Gordon, has this persistent feeling of being more than a little bit "off" that I found incredibly compelling.

I also somehow missed all these years that what makes Half-Life so beloved is that it's NOT your average hardcore FPS.  The gameplay acts as a conduit for the world and story, not the other way around.  The entire first two chapters are dedicated purely to worldbuilding, with zero combat until Chapter 3.  Most of the enemy encounters are set up to be very puzzle-like, with ways to optimize them using the environment and the tools at your disposal, rather than having to rely on quick shooting (though having a keyboard and mouse to shoot quickly and accurately when needed sure helped!).  I spent much of my playtime purposely redoing sections over and over to try and figure out the best paths forward.   I ended up taking a lot of intentional deaths just to learn the layout and experiment with different ways of navigating it, which is something this game shares with one of my favorite series: Metroid.  Gordon is a scientist, not a soldier, and the gameplay reflects that.

It's also surprisingly varied chapter-by-chapter.  Each chapter adds something new, and different players will respond differently to each of the "gimmicks", with different players having unique chapters they find especially fun or challenging.  It's a remarkably clever game, and I found myself frequently smiling at the novelty of different sections.  It doesn't necessarily do everything well, but it tries many things that would be too risky for more conservative developers to even consider, and that keeps it feeling fresh throughout.

That being said, the game does have its downsides.  Even with all of the updates in the 25th anniversary edition I still found myself encountering a lot of visual glitches, a few of which forced me to have to restart from my last save.  The game also notoriously ends on a sour note, and I have to agree with the people who say the Xen sections of the game are the weakest.  There are aspects I love about them, particularly with regards to the lore implications for the aliens, but they involve a lot of clunky platforming and a new enemy type that is a pain in the butt to fight on awkward terrain.  It also has one of the most bafflingly terrible final bosses in anything I've ever played, which is a shame.

Overall, I'm really fond of this game despite its shortcomings, and there's a lot more I could say.  It's a major piece of gaming history that deserves to be experienced, and this is a great time to play it!  The Half-Life bundle is also a hell of a deal, particularly if you get it on sale like I did.

Enemies felt like bullet sponges, and the overall experience is more frustrating than enjoyable, especially when they put a headcrab right out of side to chip away at your valuable health, or decide to spawn a vortigaunt right behind you out of nowhere. Maybe being surprised like that is fun for some people, maybe it's a good strategy for the aliens, but it just made the game less fun for me.

Having recently beaten Half-Life on my Steam Deck (which it has been optimized for, including an updated control scheme with proper analog movement!), I wanted to share my thoughts on it.  I'd only played the PS2 version many years ago, so this was a quite a drastic upgrade over my prior experience with the game, and I can say I now fully understand it's reputation as one of the greatest games of all time.

The game is dated visually, but still able to convey a strong sense of atmosphere and isolation, along with good environmental variety.  The music is sparse, but all the more memorable for it, and it adds considerably to the game's already strong atmosphere.  Compared to Half-Life 2 and other modern games, the story is sparse and simple, but it's told in an effective and interesting way.  You are always in control of protagonist Gordon Freeman, and the story never leaves his perspective for cutscenes or anything else.  It was incredibly novel and innovative in 1998, and remains effective today.

The gameplay is where Half-Life truly shines.  The shooting is solid and fun, with a good variety of weapons and enemies, and surprisingly great enemy AI that makes most encounters fairly challenging, and always keeps you on your toes.  Enemies will try to flank you, toss grenades to flush you out of cover, retreat to their comrades when injured, and so on.  The game's true strength is in it's pacing and level design, however.

The game is always throwing new things at you, and every level introduces some new feature or gimmick.  There are numerous environmental puzzles, platforming, highly interactive enviroments where if you think you can do something, you often can, and even some extremely difficult combat encounters that practically require approaching them in a creative way or using the environment to your advantage (or even occasionally just plain old running away!).  It's brilliant stuff, and all paced perfectly.  There are some end game levels that have received criticism in the years since the game's release for being a bit different from the rest of the game, but personally I enjoyed them as a change of pace, and really liked the finale a lot, overall.

The game isn't perfect, of course.  The level of challenge is surprisingly high, and while that is by no means a bad thing, it can occasionally start to feel like trial and error.  There were certain encounters and obstacles that felt like you were practically meant to die to them the first time you play, and it felt as though the game was almost kind of encouraging quicksaving/loading (AKA save scumming) at times, which is kind of questionable and hurts the immersion the game otherwise strives for and largely achieves with flying colors.  I would also definitely recommend that if you're going to play with a controller (or the Steam Deck itself), as I did, that you use one with gyro functionality as well (say, a Dualsense or Switch Pro controller, or the Deck itself with it's built in gyro), as the game was really designed for a level of precision aiming that analog sticks just can't replicate on their own.  Also, platforming is sometimes a bit fiddly and awkward due to the fast movement of the game, although it generally works well for the most part, and is improved with the newly added analog movement.

In summary, Half-Life is a near perfect video game that achieves pretty much everything it set out to do.  It's an immersive, atmospheric FPS with fun and very challenging combat, a decent (and compellingly and uniquely told) story, and some of the best level design and pacing of any game ever.  It was also a truly groundbreaking title for it's time that largely holds up brilliantly today, and that everyone who loves video games owes to themselves to experience at least once.

Now after the start of the year in 2024 i suddenly got a urge to play it til the end, and i am so happy I did. I truly understand now why this game is such an important game for the entire FPS genre, every big shooter that came after it has been inspired by this game in one way or another. It's a game where every combat encounter is it's own puzzle to solve, and the game is paced really well with interesting dialogue that isn't shoved in ur face in 5 min cutscenes every 2 mins of gameplay, instead you choose how much you want to care about the story, and you have to pay attention to pick up all the pieces. The gameplay holds up really well in this game and the AI of the enemies is really impressive for it's time, the ai is still more intelligent than some games coming out today.

I recommend Half-life even in the modern age of games, and if you can't stand the dated graphics you can play the much more modern looking and feeling Black Mesa remake of HL1.
It's fun, but i'm pretty sure you will get lost often and have no choice but to look up playthrough video in order to see what is the next step.

Glad I finally got to experience the classic. This game has excellent world building, atmosphere and story. I will admit it hasn't aged perfectly (feels quite janky at times) but that's expected given its age. The difficulty on normal was also on point, it was hard but not too hard and the quick save feature definitely makes the game more accessible despite its difficulty. I am really looking forward to playing the spin-offs (Blue Shift and Opposing Force) and am even more excited to play Black Mesa with my beast rig. The ending was really good. The Half-Life universe is definitely filled with mystery and intrigue and I look forward to getting more answers provided that the sequels/spin-offs provide them or can live up to the quality of this first game. If you think you might want to experience Half-Life I would highly recommend it. Its worth checking out due to the great story, atmosphere and good level design. The game frequently goes on sale, I would highly recommend picking it up during one.

This is an old game, and it shows. The core gameplay holds up remarkably well; the shooting is as fun as ever. However, some of the other stuff is obtuse enough I had to use a walkthrough at a few points. For examples: the water surface texture in some areas is entirely opaque, so I didn't realize where I could surface and kept drowning. There's not that much story, but what is there is communicated well with Valve's trademark storytelling style that prioritizes player control even during story segments. The graphics are awful, though. Looking forward to trying out Black Mesa and HL2 in that respect.

Overall, I recommend it, because it is a good deal of fun and a steal at $0.99. But if you've got the funds... maybe skip this and go for Black Mesa.

As a side note, I played through the entire game with a controller and no aim assist. Gyro aiming made this totally doable and fun. It's absolutely wild that I'm playing a 26 year old computer game with a Nintendo controller, making use of gyro aim and analog movement. Though I will say, the analog movement doesn't do certain platforming challenges any favors, as they were designed with WASD in mind. For me, it was easy enough to switch to my keyboard and back for those segments, but YMMV.

"Half-Life 1: A Timeless Masterpiece That Paved the Way for Gaming Greatness"

Rating: ★★★★★

If there's one game that stands as a testament to the evolution of the gaming industry, it's Half-Life 1. Released in 1998, this classic first-person shooter not only redefined the genre but laid the foundation for the immersive, narrative-driven experiences we enjoy today.

From the moment you step into the shoes of Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist caught in a disastrous experiment gone wrong, you're plunged into a gripping tale of survival. Half-Life 1 excels in storytelling without relying on cutscenes, seamlessly integrating narrative elements into the gameplay, immersing you in the mysterious and hostile world of the Black Mesa Research Facility.

The level design in Half-Life 1 is nothing short of genius. Each area is meticulously crafted to provide a perfect balance of exploration, combat, and puzzle-solving. The game introduces innovative mechanics and environmental puzzles that were groundbreaking for its time, creating a dynamic and engaging experience that keeps you on your toes.

One of Half-Life 1's standout features is the AI, which was revolutionary at the time. The enemies exhibit realistic behaviors, adapting to your tactics and making each encounter unique and challenging. The inclusion of scripted sequences and memorable set pieces adds a cinematic quality that was ahead of its time, leaving an indelible mark on the gaming landscape.

The atmosphere and soundtrack contribute significantly to the overall experience. The haunting ambient music enhances the tension, while the environmental sounds immerse you in the eerie silence of the Black Mesa facility. Combined, these elements create an atmosphere that is both captivating and spine-chilling, adding an extra layer of depth to the game.

Even after more than two decades, Half-Life 1's impact is still felt in modern gaming. The modding community has kept the game alive, with countless fan-made creations that showcase the enduring appeal of this masterpiece.

In summary, Half-Life 1 is not just a game; it's a piece of gaming history that has stood the test of time. Whether you're a veteran gamer nostalgic for the classics or a newcomer eager to explore the roots of the FPS genre, Half-Life 1 is an essential experience that deserves its status as a timeless masterpiece. Prepare for an unforgettable journey through the corridors of Black Mesa and witness the birth of a gaming legend.

Ah, the magnum opus that is Half-Life, an undeniably magnificent jewel within the grand tapestry of electronic diversions, a veritable siren's call to the intrepid gamer's soul. Picture, if you will, the heart-pounding fervor as one thrusts headlong into the verdant heart of the African jungle, where gargantuan arthropods, seemingly spawned from the wildest recesses of imagination, await with bated breath.

Now, let's delve into the weapon of choice—the crowbar, a colossus among melee instruments, a gargantuan implement that stretches the very limits of practicality with its exact width meticulously measured at a jaw-dropping 10 centimeters. This is not a mere tool; it's a symphony of destruction, an overture of chaos, a roaring crescendo of gameplay prowess that defies all preconceived notions of virtual armaments. To wield such a formidable and precise instrument in a game ostensibly intended for a younger audience is nothing short of audacious, a testament to the game's unapologetic embrace of the extraordinary.

As we navigate this eccentric virtual realm, our protagonist, a scholarly avatar adorned in the regalia of a theoretical physics laureate, stands before the colossal insects, armed with the aforementioned 10-centimeter-wide crowbar. The vivid imagery evokes a sense of sheer audacity—a juxtaposition so extraordinary that it catapults the gaming experience into realms of unparalleled eccentricity.

Now, consider the force needed to dispatch these titanic arthropods with the crowbar. Let's introduce a variable—let's call it 'F' for force. The sheer kinetic energy required to annihilate such colossal foes can be expressed mathematically as F = m * a, where 'm' represents mass and 'a' represents acceleration. The force exerted, a virtual Herculean strength, is an astounding numerical value that pushes the boundaries of what one might consider plausible in the realm of digital physics.

And in the midst of this digital odyssey, let us not forget the scientific meaning of "half-life." In the realm of nuclear physics, it denotes the time required for a quantity to reduce by half through decay—a concept that echoes the ephemerality of our virtual exploits and the fleeting nature of the challenges faced within the extraordinary world of Half-Life.

Yet, the saga deepens with a nuance that beguiles the very fabric of reason. Our erudite protagonist, bearing the lofty mantle of a theoretical physics degree, undertakes a perilous odyssey in pursuit of enigmatic crystals. Imagine, if you will, the sheer audacity of a scholar, normally ensconced in the rarefied air of intellectual pursuits, now thrust into the tumultuous maelstrom of crystal retrieval—an endeavor that defies the very tenets of scholarly disposition.

In this convolution of virtual narratives, we witness our academic luminary forsaking the hallowed halls of contemplative musings for the frontline trenches of crystal retrieval—a narrative detour so peculiar that it surpasses the boundaries of imagination. The querulous pondering remains: Should not this learned individual, steeped in the arcane arts of theoretical physics, be more aptly suited for contemplative inquiry than venturing into the tempest of experimental perils?

Ah, my esteemed conversationalist, the chronicles of virtual storytelling transcend the mundane, leaving us to traverse surreal landscapes with nought but a furrowed brow and a sense of bewildered enchantment. Such is the captivating enigma that is Half-Life, where exaggeration meets the extraordinary, and the force required to dispatch monstrous foes adds a thrilling layer of numerical intricacy to this audacious brilliance.
This game is, despite its age,*still* more fun than most recent singleplayer games. If you haven't done it already, play it!

It is definitely a product of its time. I can see how it affected many games to come, but the speedy quick movement just did not feel right. Especially when you mix it with the platforming. Obviously the graphics are old and do not really get in the way aside from understanding damage numbers, but also tracking missiles and such. But overall the game can be easily and simply played through by saving after every encounter which is how I played it. If you wanted to play through with the auto save system, you are a better man than I. For 99 cents this was pretty fun and I would recommend it, but the game play starts to get boring after a while. The inconsistent way to get ammo mixed with weird timing of health packs made some missions just a breeze and others you had to properly conserve ammo. I only went to a walk-through guide twice and found the answer to be obvious, I was just impatient. This game is a pretty straightforward experience and I am glad I have finally done the pilgrimage to the game that inspired many. Oh also, the game reminded me of Far Cry 1 in many many ways, like an incredible amount of ways. Just replace really fast sporadic movement with vehicles and they were the same experience.

When I was but a wee-lad, I played this game on PS2. It's an incredible port that has a lot to offer to fans of the series. It features a lot of changes in level design and mechanics; even built in support for mouse and keyboard for those interested. in all honesty, I prefer it to the PC version. That said, the PC version is good too. I love the early levels very much. The pacing and set pieces keep you on you toes at all times. However the game is not without issues.
The real issue with the game is Xen. I never realized how much of an issue it was until I played the PC version. Outside of the infamous chapter's set pieces and bosses, Xen is tiresome. For one, it's too long and drags, especially during interloper. Second, some of the platforming is incredibly dull. However, Xen is not the only issue. 
Introducing: the flying b**tards, aka, the Controllers- I hate these things. The problem is not that their hard to hit, or anything about their unfairness, but rather that they come in packs, usually, five or more. 
Two shots from your revolver or two bolts from your crossbow, takes them down, but it's hard to focus on them when there are two or more vortigaunts rapidly blasting you with moutain dew colored lighting bolts. It makes fighting them more cumbersome than it should be. By no means the worst enemy design, but far from the best Half Life has to offer. A quick aside, fighting controllers is less of an issue in the PS2 version because of the lock-on-aim-assist. Just lock on and shoot, done. 
Office complex is by far my favorite part of the game. I love running through the hallways blasting aliens and scientists indiscriminately. The way it interlocks and weaves you back and forth between set pieces is excellent. You never feel like you're backtracking because there's always something new to offer. 
Overall Half Life is a good game. I recommend the PC version, but if you're willing to invest a little more time and money I really recommend the PS2 version.

Even though im a huge source engine fan, i honestly prefer this over the sequel any day!
It has more weapons, smarter AI that still impress me to this day, faster movement and more diverse environments.
The long jump module is the best powerup ever put in a game.

While the plot itself is nothing special (in my opinion) the way the story is told through gameplay rather than pre rendered cutscenes or dialogue boxes is simply brilliant as it keeps you immersed at all time rather than making you wonder why the rest of the game dont look as good as the CGI movie the publisher forced in.
Its the textbook example of Show Don't Tell, or in game terms: Play dont Show!
While i also love those games, this game is the direct opposite of the Metal Gear series with a simpler plot that is only told though what you as a player would know at any time.
Sometimes less is more especially if it can be used across language barriers or to not interrupt the fun for speedrunners.

And even if you dont care about the simple plot of Gorgeous Freemont cleaning up the mess he caused, this game constantly rewards you with gameplay thats the perfect mix of adrenaline gorged speed, slow atmospheric horror and cerebral tactics from the muli use weapons and the enemy patterns.

Even with the tanky power armour, Gordon is still a frail glass canon.
While enemies can deal insane damage really fast, due to their predictable patterns it never feels unfair or broken. With every enemy being a CS player having to tediously stand still in order to shoot you, the game uses that to silently encourage you as a player to play it as a fun movement shooter by moving in, dealing damage and using your movement to dodge damage as you move out.
To win you must run, think, shoot and live to repeat the process another day.

Even the most powerfull weapons you get in the late game dont feel braindead as they use scarce ammo (that can sometimes share ammopool with worse weapons) and can just as easially damage and kill its own user really fast if you're not carefull.
I love weapons that can be used as tools or that are super powerfull with serious downsides to really make you think when it is a good time to use them.

Also for me the best part is opening the console and typing in the speak command followed by a textstring of whatever dumb stuff you want the VOX or HCU to say.

"Gordon...Freeman's...ass...is...opened!"

"Dr Coomer...Is...Engaged...with...Calhoun"

Its also a fast game to load steam overlay on for when you must google stuff for essays and not be recommended the most random crap afterwards. (Albeit a little bit slower after the update due to the new intro that is STILL NOT the valve guy drilling a valve into his head.)

Honestly goated game; I fucking loved every second of this game. Lemme give you some backstory:
I've always heard of HL and how good a franchise it is and I even had played like half of HL2 but never finished it, but one day, out of the blue, I just decided to launch this game and try to play it. And boy, did I love it. The way this story is structured is so that you are always at the center of the story and you are always playing how you want. I feel when the combat was light and unique (which it often was unique) it was excellent. I loved the use of the different weapons and the tactics on the enemies and how you could fight them in a multitude of different ways and strategies. But occasionally in the too-combat-heavy sections it did tend to drag a bit when you just kept save-scumming and just had to try to brute force your way through that level. But other than that I loved the feel of this game and how it felt so simple yet complex and rich. I loved the subtle build of the G-Man and how you see him following you. I loved the interactions between the characters and how it gave off little bits of lore if you stopped and looked at the levels or listened to the scientists. One of my favorite moments was when you finally go outside, it was such a weirdly good feeling because it seemed like such a mundane thing but in this game after being indoors the whole time, finally going outside in surface tension and seeing the blue sky contrasted between the deep orange cliff edges and the grey metallic laboratories was something else. This game inspired me to play the rest of this series and seriously begin to consider going into game design as a career because seeing the story of early valve making a legendary and revolutionary game like this as their first game with a little team is incredibly inspiring, even after all of the scummy and disheartening practices they've come to do throughout the years.

[h2] Half-Life, a wonderful trip back to the 90's [/h2]

   DOOM and QUAKE had already laid the foundations for what a good shooter of the time had to be, but it would not be until the arrival of a Valve in its infancy that the genre would take its next giant step, specifically with Valve's debut release, Half -Life and the enormous changes that this meant in the market.

   Released on November 8, 1998, Half-Life is a first-person shooter with puzzle elements which takes place in a science fiction universe in the early 2000s, in which we take the role of a highly trained young scientist. who after a serious failed experiment, must face all kinds of abominations until he finds a solution to the chaos.

[b] Below, a list of positive and negative points experienced during my time playing and free of spoilers (do not consider this as an absolute truth, but as what it is, a simple opinion) [/b]

[h3] What did I like? [/h3]

🟩   [b] The story. [/b] It presents a simple story which can be delved into very easily, explaining in detail the reason for everything, along with a large number of unknowns.

🟩   [b] The gameplay. [/b] It is the next big step in action since QUAKE, frenetic in combat, but it also has puzzle sections to think about, everything being well planned.

🟩   [b] The music. [/b] It's 100% personal, but I consider many songs made for this title to be really enjoyable songs even beyond their purpose within the title.

[h3] What did I NOT like? [/h3]
 
⬜   [b] No-uh. [/b] I didn't find anything that really bothered me.


[h3] What should I take into account when playing? [/h3]

❕ [b] Nope, nothing. [/b] There really is nothing relevant to take into account beyond playing.

[h3] Personal opinion. [/h3]

   It represents the next great step in the evolution of shooters, but in addition to that, it is a title ahead of its time, full of life, action and a story that today fills everyone who plays it with intrigue, a gem. For anyone who appreciates the history of this genre.

Half-Life: 1998:

Gameplay: We are a Theoretical Physicist from Harvard University named Gordon Freeman, employees of Black Mesa, a company that is dedicated to experimenting with teleportation, our task was to do a teleportation test but something goes wrong which they send us for help to fix This mess, the journey is a bit long but the more we play several things will become clearer. The game was developed by VALVe in 1998 with its CD format, which I was able to try in a good way at the time. The game revolutionized the video game genre, being the first in 3D with the GoldSource engine, thus being able to have a wide combat experience and incredibly detailed scenarios.

Maps: The maps are quite good and the truth is that they have not looked bad at all, despite the years that have passed.

Soundtrack: The soundtrack is great, it actually has good songs that were mostly used for its expansions.

Achievements: This game has no achievements.

DLC: Includes downloadable content being Half-Life: 1998, Opposing Force, Blue Shift and Team Fortress Classic.

Postscript: Happy 25th Anniversary of Half-Life !

After coming back to this game after first playing it a little more than 9 years ago, my second play through was just as enjoyable as I remember. It's still, of course, a game of its time, with some weird bugs here and there - with doors that will drain away your health, enemies that get stuck and stand still, and being able to skip through some portions of the map you're not supposed to go, slipping into others - but despite these quirks, it still doesn't distract from the pretty enjoyable story and game play. The fun arsenal of weapons, the charming attention to detail, blast jumping and running around like a maniac, and surviving a fall of 100 meters into a foot of water, are all staples which still hold their enjoyable traits. Black Mesa is a wonderful, beautifully reconstructed version of this game, which I highly recommend, but I don't think it can totally replace this retro dive-in. It's something I recommend on sale, in tandem with Black Mesa, Hope to be back playing this in another decade.
