Half-Life, especially with the recent 25th Anniversary Update, is a fantastic title that while the graphics are certainly showing it's age, the game is fun, challenging, and awesome.

For those that don't know, Half-Life is revolutionary in quite a few ways.  Building off of the Quake Engine in what became called the GoldSrc engine (retroactively named after the release of the Source Engine), the game is most known, in my opinion, for how the game is experienced.  In other titles, there are cutscenes that exist before you gain control of the character.  Opening Credits might also be a thing, and all in all, you're going to have no control over your character.  In this game, you've got control over the main character, Gordon Freeman, for about 99% of the game, and the entirety of it is viewed through his eyes.  The introduction as you ride the monorail to your destination?  You can move around.  Is there a creature that gets introduced?  You can walk into it head-on.  Is a helicopter flying in but you don't care because you're busy finding cover?  You can do that and look out when it's safe.

Speaking of story, Half-Life pioneered storytelling in the FPS Genre.  Before, things were mainly a matter of run-and-gun.  And Half-Life [i]can[/i] be played that way, but it doesn't need to be.  The whole intro sequence has you commuting to work, essentially.  No guns, no combat.  The first "weapon" you get?  A crowbar.  And if you're particularly good with that crowbar in the very beginning, you won't even have access to a gun (in that you actually keep the security guards safe, until you encounter the first already-dead guard).

Enemy AI (not large language models, but the subroutines enemy characters perform to attack you) was also a big leap - instead of mindlessly going towards you when near, enemies will actually try to flank you, move to better vantage points, and take cover or [b]regroup to get help and attack in numbers[/b].

Half-Life also pioneered unique ways to reduce load times; most of the time, the game doesn't take long to load when going from area-to-area, and every "level" feels connected to a larger world.  Instead of reaching a goal with a results screen like Doom, or an ending cutscene, [i]you[/i] walk down the corridor to the next room (with maybe a 3 second pause).  YOU are the one who starts the new "level" by climbing up the elevator shaft.  YOU are the one in control of levels, and can sometimes move in and out of these areas.

That said, there's plenty of rough edges to the game.  Literally and figuratively.  Literally, in that the poly count is low.  It's a game from the end of the 90s, and it shows.  PROTIP: Disable texture filtering.  Textures look more pixelated, but they look a lot better, in my opinion, than when they're blurry given the low resolution.  Otherwise, the graphics certainly are primitive, but another pioneered tech is used here - skeletal animation.  Something not frequently used in games and allowed more dynamic animation options.  Audio is certainly lower quality given the time period, and there are some glitches here and there that warrant re-loading the game.  I personally had one incident towards the end of the game, one of the big bosses - it's AI broke, so instead of running away to another phase of the fight, it just... hung around and kept trying to attack me.  I had to load an earlier save, luckily one that was just before the second phase, so I didn't have to completely start from scratch.

All in all, it's a great game, and definitely worth playing.  And if you want a better experience, do NOT go for Half-Life: Source, which simply ports the game as-is to the Source Engine.  It's considered vastly inferior, however do consider Black Mesa - a fan project that completely remasters and remakes the first game, with many quality of life improvements that are found in the Source games.  It looks so good that it fits in with the Half-Life 2 games, but that's a review for another day...

Half-life (symbol t½) is the time required for a quantity (of substance) to reduce to half of its initial value. The term is commonly used in nuclear physics to describe how quickly unstable atoms undergo radioactive decay or how long stable atoms survive. The term is also used more generally to characterize any type of exponential (or, rarely, non-exponential) decay. For example, the medical sciences refer to the biological half-life of drugs and other chemicals in the human body. The converse of half-life (in exponential growth) is doubling time.

The original term, half-life period, dating to Ernest Rutherford's discovery of the principle in 1907, was shortened to half-life in the early 1950s.[1] Rutherford applied the principle of a radioactive element's half-life in studies of age determination of rocks by measuring the decay period of radium to lead-206.

Half-life is constant over the lifetime of an exponentially decaying quantity, and it is a characteristic unit for the exponential decay equation. The accompanying table shows the reduction of a quantity as a function of the number of half-lives elapsed.

This game has been praised by a lot of people for a good reason. I still think it holds up quite well if you can overlook the graphics (which I don't mind at all) and some annoying level design.

For a game this old the gameplay is still really good. All enemies are different and there is quite a good variety in them, the combat in general just feels good because you have multiple ways in tackling encounters. I liked the movement too, you can bhop and surf on some surfaces, moving around in this game feels good.

The game has great atmosphere, some parts are quite scary and you really feel like Gordon Freeman. There is good variety in levels, some feel samey but they all have something unique about them. Like I already stated, some levels are a bit confusing so I had to consult a walkthrough a handful of times. I also wasn't a big fan of the last couple levels and the final boss but those are really my only complaints.

The game also supports ultrawide (21:9).

I played through the game on normal difficulty and felt like it was a decent challenge, from what I have heard hard just makes enemies damage sponges so I recommend going with normal. I did use quicksaves, without them the game would be quite hard, even on normal.

Definitely get this if you like singleplayer shooters, the game still holds up incredibly well.

So, Half-Life.  Some people think this game is a rip-off of the works of Stephen King, H.P. Lovecraft, and H.R. Giger.  Those people are incorrect, it also rips off the work of Clark Ashton Smith.  Valve might not think anyone knows the headcrabs are rip-offs of the leeches from Smith's short story "The Vaults of Yoh-Vombis" but I know, Valve.  I know.

But, obvious creative influences aside, this game is a classic because it's good.  The story is good, the world building is good, and the NPC interactions and gunplay are excellent for the 90s.  My only complain is the ladder physics.  There so bad it's distracting, because clearly everything else in the game has a lot of work put into it.  You'll constantly slip of the ladders, and when you do, you'll take a huge amount of fall damage.  Get used to hearing the H.E.V suit say "fracture detected" because it's going to happen a lot.  The game has some platforming sections too.  First person 3D platforming sucks even in the present, and it sucked in the 90s too.  You'll find yourself saving before every jump just because of how easy it is to miss or slip off platforms.  

Also, and this is a nit pick, it doesn't make sense that the H.E.V chargers run out of power.  It's not like the facility has a power outage or anything.  Also, why do they only charge the suit to 50 percent?  I know it makes sense from a gameplay balance perspective but it doesn't make sense from how an actual charger would work.  I mean, the first aid things only have so much healing whatever in them, but a charger is a charger.  Also, the H.E.V suit is called that for "Hazardous Environment" but the H.E.V charger has periods after each letter which suggest a three word name for the suit.  The chargers should say either H.E.S or H.Ev, not H.E.V.

Title: A Timeless Masterpiece: Half-Life's Enduring Brilliance

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Half-Life, the groundbreaking first-person shooter developed by Valve Corporation, stands as a testament to the enduring brilliance of a game that has left an indelible mark on the gaming industry since its release in 1998. Even after more than two decades, Half-Life continues to captivate players with its immersive storytelling, innovative gameplay mechanics, and groundbreaking design.

One of Half-Life's defining strengths lies in its narrative execution. The game introduces players to the silent protagonist, Gordon Freeman, a scientist at the Black Mesa Research Facility. The narrative unfolds seamlessly as players traverse through the facility, encountering unforeseen consequences of an experiment gone awry. The absence of cutscenes and the immersive first-person perspective create a sense of continuous engagement, blurring the lines between player and protagonist.

The game's pacing is masterfully crafted, with tense moments of survival horror seamlessly transitioning into high-octane action sequences. Half-Life's ability to maintain a gripping narrative without ever breaking the player's immersion is a testament to its narrative sophistication, setting a benchmark for storytelling in the FPS genre.

In terms of innovation, Half-Life introduced a groundbreaking approach to environmental storytelling and level design. The game relies on minimalistic HUD elements, encouraging players to observe their surroundings for vital information. Each level is meticulously designed, creating a sense of realism and cohesion within the game world. The use of scripted events and dynamic AI further enhances the overall sense of immersion, making every playthrough a unique experience.

A major highlight of Half-Life is the introduction of the Gravity Gun in Half-Life 2, the sequel released in 2004. This iconic weapon revolutionized the gaming landscape, allowing players to manipulate objects in the environment creatively. The physics-based gameplay added a layer of complexity and innovation that was unparalleled at the time and continues to influence game design to this day.

Half-Life's impact on the multiplayer gaming scene is equally noteworthy, with the release of Counter-Strike, a mod developed for the original game. This mod went on to become one of the most popular online shooters, showcasing the modding potential inherent in the Half-Life engine.

In conclusion, Half-Life is not merely a game; it's a timeless masterpiece that has shaped the gaming landscape. Its narrative sophistication, innovative gameplay mechanics, and pioneering design elements set a standard that few games have been able to match. Even after more than two decades, Half-Life remains a must-play for both nostalgic fans and new generations of gamers, standing tall as a testament to the enduring brilliance of a true gaming classic.

This game is old. That is not a bad thing, people still play games like Age of Empires II and that one came out a year after Half-Life. Older games that were successful back in the day may fall in the pits of nostalgia, and a fresher look sometimes reveal shortcomings. The 25th anniversary seemed like a good time to revisit the game and see if it holds up. I may be biased as I did play the game many years ago, but my nostalgia lies closer to the sequel, Half-Life 2.

Let's start with the performance: being old, the game can run on low end computers without issues ([i] the reviewer used an almost 10 years old laptop[/i] ). This is not one of those games that refuses to work in newer OS ( [i] Windows 10 here [/i] ).

The graphics hold up, the style and the lighting carry the game but whenever you are outside the research complex you remember more acutely that this game is 25 years old, with some low-res textures. The NPCs also show the game's age (don't expect fully modeled hair strands).

The sound department is top notch. The many weapons sounds are appropriate and feel impactful. Each enemy has a set of sounds and you will end identifying many of them first by sound. On top of that, you can tell where the noise comes from, more so if you are using a headset; you may not see an enemy right away but you can tell they are nearby.
Music is used sparingly, but when it shows up you're in for a ride (don't forget to add the soundtrack to your Steam account, it's free).

Gameplay is interesting. While mainly a FPS, Half-Life uses a lot of platforming, you will be jumping all over the place, but there's plenty of more conventional shooting. Did I hear shooting? This game has a lot of weapons, not just guns, each one with their own ammo and, while some weapons are stronger than others, you will end using all of them, as some are better suited for certain tasks.

The AI does its job. The NPCs don't stay still waiting for you to shoot them, in fact different enemies behave in unique ways, in time you will learn their behaviour. At certain points friendly NPCs will be needed to advance the game but thankfully there are not escort missions.

All the previous points come together to create set pieces, where the player will have to use all these elements to solve a puzzle of sorts. Here the physics of the game will come into play. The game is linear, you go from one crafted experience to the next, but still there's a degree of exploration at points that rewards the player with more resources for the challenges ahead. There are no quick time events, but the game will demand reflexes to overcome its challenges. Sometimes you may dislike one section of the game, but the next one most likely will attempt something different. Now, being honest, the ending of the game will increase the platforming to a point some will find annoying since the gravity pull will be decreased, but these are short levels and not bad enough to ruin the game.

Still unsure? Well, this game has labcoats, grenades, a monorail system, water terror, waste management, a lack of OSHA regulations, gruesome deaths, air ducts and much, much more. Also, there's multiplayer, if you want to try free form gameplay.

Now, some [b] advice [/b] sounds nice. First, your game may have auto-aim on by default; if you are using the good old keyboard/mouse combo, you may feel it's redundant, it's easy to turn off in the settings. Second, some of the platforming is finicky; if you doubt wheter you can make the jump, quick save (F6 by default) before painfully crashing to chain attempts with quick load (F7 by default). Occasionally the game may have minor issues, loading a previous save will solve them (the game autosaves frequently). Also, yes, you can destroy [spoiler] the tanks [/spoiler] , they don't show the damage until they explode, so you may wonder if you are wasting ammo.

In sum, I recommend this game. Some of its ideas are more commonplace nowadays but you will still have a good time.

From the moment I first stepped into the shoes of Dr. Gordon Freeman in the iconic Black Mesa Research Facility, I realised that Half-Life was more than just a game; it's a monumental experience. Having played it now, years after its initial release in 1998, I'm thrilled to say that it still holds up remarkably well.

The game's strength lies in its ability to blend a compelling narrative with immersive gameplay seamlessly. The story unfolds organically, eschewing cutscenes, and instead, relies on environmental storytelling and scripted events that keep you engaged. It's a testament to Valve's innovative design philosophy, which was groundbreaking at the time and still feels fresh today.

Graphically, whilst it shows its age, there's a certain charm to the visuals that adds to the game's nostalgic value. The level design is intricate and thoughtfully laid out, encouraging exploration and rewarding curiosity. The sound design, from the eerie silence of deserted labs to the sudden, heart-pounding music during action sequences, adds to the overall atmosphere, making Black Mesa feel like a real, lived-in place.

Half-Life's gameplay is a balanced mix of puzzle-solving, exploration, and combat. The AI of both allies and enemies is impressive, even by today's standards. The weapon variety and the innovative use of the Gravity Gun provide a satisfying combat experience.

However, it's not without its flaws. The platforming sections can be frustrating, and some might find the graphics too dated. But these are minor gripes in what is otherwise a masterful piece of gaming history.

To new players, Half-Life offers a glimpse into the evolution of the FPS genre, and to veterans, it's a nostalgic trip back to one of the finest games ever made. It's a must-play, not just for fans of the genre, but for anyone interested in the history of video games. Valve didn't just make a game; they crafted a legacy that has stood the test of time.

Rating: 9/10 - A masterpiece that remains as compelling today as it was in 1998.

Half-life (symbol t½) is the time required for a quantity (of substance) to reduce to half of its initial value. The term is commonly used in nuclear physics to describe how quickly unstable atoms undergo radioactive decay or how long stable atoms survive. The term is also used more generally to characterize any type of exponential (or, rarely, non-exponential) decay. For example, the medical sciences refer to the biological half-life of drugs and other chemicals in the human body. The converse of half-life (in exponential growth) is doubling time.

The original term, half-life period, dating to Ernest Rutherford's discovery of the principle in 1907, was shortened to half-life in the early 1950s.[1] Rutherford applied the principle of a radioactive element's half-life in studies of age determination of rocks by measuring the decay period of radium to lead-206.

Half-life is constant over the lifetime of an exponentially decaying quantity, and it is a characteristic unit for the exponential decay equation. The accompanying table shows the reduction of a quantity as a function of the number of half-lives elapsed.

Half Life is one of the greatest First-Person Shooters ever made. 

Its fast paced gameplay combined with the intense variety of its weapons creates a unique FPS experience. The design of the maps facilitates, but does not require, using the "right tool for the job." Because of this, Half Life is extremely replayable. Your knowledge of the maps and weapon abilities increase with each playthrough, so it's extremely satisfying when you can find a novel and unique way to get the upper hand on the enemies.

The sound design is also top notch. The world feels alive and real. The guns sound crisp. The soundtrack, though rare, shines when it arrives. 

And it's still that good 25 years later.

Overrated turd. Ladder climbing mechanics are garbage. Often you are required to jump to a ladder, and you will fall to your death because you don't stick. I had to look it up and it turns out you can't have any buttons held in before touching a ladder. Why? I dunno, but that's a terrible mechanic. Getting off of ladders is clunky too. 

Has cheap difficulty, often enemies will pop out of nowhere with no warning. I remember getting shot to death by turrets because two Vortigunts spawned behind me and activated the laser sensor. Has cheap hazards like things suddenly falling from the ceiling that do a ton of damage that wait for you to get close before it activates with no warning. You're forced to take things slow to avoid those hazards. The way hazards activate you'd think you were playing on a Death Run server.

Blast Pit is a bad example. Has a tentacle monster that can keep hitting you while you can't kill it. Only stun each tentacle (for a very short time) separately with your guns and explosives. God forbid you run out of ammo. It's possible to distract it by banging on the walls on the outside before going in. Or you can throw a grenade to lure it to wherever you threw it. But the game doesn't tell you ANY of this. I had to look it up. 

Before I found out about the grenade trick, I was trying to sneak past the monster and got to the third ladder, then there's a bunch of ḟṵcking boxes blocking the top. So in order to climb through you have to destroy the boxes, which makes noise, then the monster knows where you are and kills you.  

If you don't bang on the walls and sneak, the monster will camp at the doorway waiting for you to enter so it can attack you right away. Which then, spamming your weapons to stun is the only way past. And you'll take a bunch of damage in the process. Horrible game design.

There are multiple points in the game where you can get softlocked out of progression because your HP is too low. Like fall damage from high jumps or long falls you have to do to get to the next area. Rooms filled with smg & grenade spamming soldiers coming from multiple sides. Instant death, no time to shoot back and kill them. If you have no armor and low health left, you're just sḧít out of luck alot of the time. 

Then you have the bugs, parts of the map that move that you're meant to stand on can instakill you if you collide with them wrong. On the elevator in Power Up, if you kill the soldiers while they're still on it. Then you ride the elevator while touching the bodies, you'll explode. No, really. And railroad thing you drive can explode you too if you touch it the wrong way. I found that out trying to jump back on it while it was passing by and ended up touching a front corner.

This game is outdated, cheap not challenging. I can't recommend it

All-in-all, the level design of Half-Life exceeds standards that Triple A studios try to achieve nowadays.  While being a linear game, it doesn't feel like you're being forced down a straight path.  

The hardest difficultly is challenging but not too difficult.

Half-life (symbol t½) is the time required for a quantity (of substance) to reduce to half of its initial value. The term is commonly used in nuclear physics to describe how quickly unstable atoms undergo radioactive decay or how long stable atoms survive. The term is also used more generally to characterize any type of exponential (or, rarely, non-exponential) decay. For example, the medical sciences refer to the biological half-life of drugs and other chemicals in the human body. The converse of half-life (in exponential growth) is doubling time.

The original term, half-life period, dating to Ernest Rutherford's discovery of the principle in 1907, was shortened to half-life in the early 1950s. Rutherford applied the principle of a radioactive element's half-life in studies of age determination of rocks by measuring the decay period of radium to lead-206.

Half-life is constant over the lifetime of an exponentially decaying quantity, and it is a characteristic unit for the exponential decay equation. The accompanying table shows the reduction of a quantity as a function of the number of half-lives elapsed. 

Probabilistic nature

A half-life often describes the decay of discrete entities, such as radioactive atoms. In that case, it does not work to use the definition that states "half-life is the time required for exactly half of the entities to decay". For example, if there is just one radioactive atom, and its half-life is one second, there will not be "half of an atom" left after one second.

Instead, the half-life is defined in terms of probability: "Half-life is the time required for exactly half of the entities to decay on average". In other words, the probability of a radioactive atom decaying within its half-life is 50%.

For example, the accompanying image is a simulation of many identical atoms undergoing radioactive decay. Note that after one half-life there are not exactly one-half of the atoms remaining, only approximately, because of the random variation in the process. Nevertheless, when there are many identical atoms decaying (right boxes), the law of large numbers suggests that it is a very good approximation to say that half of the atoms remain after one half-life.

Various simple exercises can demonstrate probabilistic decay, for example involving flipping coins or running a statistical computer program.

Half-Life is undoubtedly the best first person shooter I have ever played. The way it blends action and suspense together is one of the many reasons why it is so good. The game allows for immersive game play and storytelling through the way it plays out. Every cut scene is in first person, and clear transition allows for real-time chapter telling. The fact that, in a first person shooter, there would only be scripted sequences and no cut scenes in third person would be unthinkable in today's standards. The enemies feel realistic and the game play is, well, realistic. It is also difficult in every setting and combines many ways of warfare into the levels. In all, Half-Life is a revolutionary game for it's time and today's time.

Method
Preheat the oven to 180C/160C Fan/Gas 4 and line 2 x 12-hole fairy cake tins with paper cases.

Cream the butter and sugar together in a bowl until pale. Beat in the eggs, a little at a time, and stir in the vanilla extract.

Fold in the flour using a large metal spoon. Add a little milk until the mixture is a soft dropping consistency and spoon the mixture into the paper cases until they are half full.

Bake in the oven for 8–10 minutes, or until golden-brown on top and a skewer inserted into one of the cakes comes out clean. Set aside to cool for 10 minutes, then remove from the tin and cool on a wire rack.

For the icing, sift the icing sugar into a large mixing bowl and stir in enough water to create a smooth mixture. Stir in the food colouring.

To ice the fairy cakes, drizzle the icing over the cakes, sprinkle with decorations and set aside until the icing hardens.

EDIT AS OF 2023:
HAPPY BELATED 25TH ANNIVERSARY HALF-LIFE! 

The content updates and bug fixes for an aging game are a highly appreciated and unexpected move from Valve. They didn't have to do anything, yet they didn't hesitate to show that they love this game just as much as we do.
Its just cool!

Half-Life, oh, where do I even begin with this iconic masterpiece? It's like a fine wine that only gets better with age, or in this case, a game that has stood the test of time and left an indelible mark on the gaming world.

Let's talk about the story—utterly captivating. From the moment Gordon Freeman steps off that tram into the Black Mesa Research Facility, you're hooked. It's a rollercoaster of scientific mishaps, interdimensional chaos, and a silent protagonist who communicates more with a crowbar than most characters do with their entire script. The narrative is so engaging that it's like being pulled into a gripping sci-fi novel that you can't put down.

The gameplay is a perfect blend of action, exploration, and puzzle-solving. It's the kind of experience that keeps you on your toes, whether you're fending off headcrabs, navigating precarious platforming sections, or outsmarting the enigmatic G-Man. The level design is a work of art, with each environment seamlessly weaving into the next, creating a cohesive and immersive world.

And let's not forget the revolutionary AI of the time. The enemies felt intelligent, reacting dynamically to your actions, making every encounter a thrilling dance of wits. The iconic crowbar became more than a weapon; it became a symbol of survival and a tool for breaking through the unexpected.

The graphics, while dated by today's standards, were groundbreaking in their time. The atmospheric and immersive environments, coupled with the hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, created an experience that transcended mere gaming. It was a journey into the unknown, where every corner held the promise of a new discovery or a deadly threat.

In conclusion, Half-Life isn't just a game; it's a cultural phenomenon that redefined the first-person shooter genre. It's a timeless classic that continues to inspire and influence game developers to this day. Gordon Freeman's journey through Black Mesa is not just a game; it's an unforgettable adventure that has left an indelible mark on the hearts of gamers worldwide.

Half-Life came out in my early teens. You've heard the story a million times but it really completely changed things. Especially for me since I hadn't played many FPS games prior. I simply didn't think video games could be... This. I was lost in this game. Absorbed in it. Every vent, every gun, every sequence, I loved it. Even Xen. I'm a Xen apologist through and through. It was daunting and alien. There isn't a moment in Half-Life I wasn't sweating during that virgin(in more ways than one) playthrough. While the illusion is long gone and I know how to fly through the game and beat the bosses, I still remember the way it all felt the first time, every time.

Half-Life is the perfect game to me. You just always remember your first. The level design is as good as it gets, still. And the way the narrative is told ambiguously through play still rarely gets matched all these years later. It has more of a sense of freedom than some open world games even though it's linear. I can't gush enough. It came together at the perfect time in gaming history with the right recipe of love and deadline crunch. It can't, hasn't, and won't ever be improved in my eyes. I even put it, well, ahead of HL2 (there are dozens of us, dozens!).

I love Half-Life. Happy (belated) anniversary.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

+ movement and shooting feels very smooth, an excellent basis for a shooter game. Not even many modern games feel so good to move and shoot.
+ Great weapon selection. You always have a way to deal with a problem.
+ Xen world really feels alien, comparable to some Morrowind areas.
+ Environment is very varied and interesting. Something happens every two minutes played.
+ Interactive environment with some light puzzling.
+ Enemy variety is great and even the most basic Vortigaunt can be pretty dangerous in groups.
+ Fun interactions with friendly NPCs and even some enemy vs enemy fights. 
+ Game can be bought incredibly cheap together with other Half life games. 
+ Graphics are excellent, game runs very well on modern hardware. UI scales well too.
+- While the story flows decently well it is very basic. Start is strong and Xen is also strong, the rest is just not that interesting.

[b]"Good morning and welcome to the Black Mesa Transit System."[/b]

Half-Life.
Just the mere mention of its name is enough to give you chills.
Many consider it the greatest FPS of all time.
Valve's founding FPS is such a masterpiece that we still feel its aura today.
Named "Game of the Year" by more than 50 magazines, it is a cult title.
It even made the terms "Doom-Like" and "Quake-Like" obsolete.
Without forgetting that this is the beginning of Valve's success story.
Is it even possible to do a purely objective review for Half-Life?

[b]"They're waiting for you, Gordon. In the test chamber."[/b]

Gordon Freeman is a scientist with a degree in theoretical physics from M.I.T., specializing in the research of "Anomalous Materials".
He is employed at the prestigious Black Mesa scientific complex.
Freeman is is entrusted with an experiment of capital importance: 
the analysis of a crystal of alien origin.
Unfortunately, contact of the sample with the anti-mass spectrometer
has "Unforeseen Consequences".
This leads to a "Resonance Cascade" of phenomenal power, 
partially destroying the research center.
Worse still, it opened an interdimensional breach through which warlike aliens emerge...
The army was called to the rescue, but was ordered to kill all the witnesses...
Gordon must then fight his way to save his colleagues and escape this hell.

[b]"You aren't scared, are you?"[/b]

One of the great strengths of Half-Life is its storytelling.
You play as Gordon Freeman and see everything through his eyes.
No cutscene or dialogue intersperses the scientist's adventures.
Everything is done so that you identify as best as possible with the character, a hero in spite of himself.

[b]"Run. Think. Shoot. Live."[/b]

Half-Life is the ultimate evolution of the 90s FPS.
It's no longer just a question of taking down enemies.
Puzzles push you to interact with the world to progress,
use levers, valves, push or pull crates, etc...
There are even vehicle sequences, with a tram "On a Rail".
The gunfights are breathtaking, the AI ​​is very clever.

[b]"Oh my God...we're doomed!"[/b]

Black Mesa is invaded by all kinds of creatures from Xen.
The soldiers shoots on sight at everything that moves, the aliens as well as the employees of the Research Center.
The Half-Life bestiary is rich and varied, each of the NPCs or creatures, allies and enemies alike, has its own behavior and animations.

The scientists and the security guards are your friends and colleagues, they only want the best for you.
In addition to giving you advices, they open certain locked doors. 
The scientists can heal you if you're wounded, and the "Barneys" can easily kill aliens like Headcrabs or Vortigaunts...

The Xen creatures are very different from each other but they all have one thing in common:
They're after you. 
Here is the list of all these alien monsters:

Headcrabs
Zombies
Vortigaunts
Houndeyes
Barnacles
Bullsquid
Tentacles
Gargantuas
Ichthyosaurs
Alien Grunts
Alien Controllers

The H.E.C.U. has been dispatched to the Research Center to stem the alien invasion,
and do everything to prevent the Black Mesa disaster from becoming known. 
These soldiers are battle-hardened, intelligent and brutal.
They have, among other things, machine guns, heavy cannons, automatic turrets,
Apache & Osprey Helicopters, F16 fighter jets, Abrams & Bradley Armored Tanks...

Black Ops Assassins are special enemies: they are the only women we fight.
An Assassin is as agile as a Kunoichi, dressed all in black.
They are as fast as lightning, and can perform spectacular jumps.
They're equipped with a silent Glock, and a huge and magnificent pair of... 
grenades attached to the belt.

[b]"Welcome to the H.E.V. Mark IV protective system, 
for use in hazardous environment conditions."[/b]

The H.E.V. Mark IV protective system is the orange suit worn by Gordon Freeman.
It is the main equipment of the series, it bears the λ symbol .
Gordon Freeman resists radioactivity, burns, electricity, and chemicals thanks to it.
It absorbs a large part of the damage received, and can be recharged using H.E.V. chargers or batteries.
The Long Jump Module allows Gordon to make great leaps forward, which proves very useful later.

[b]"Gordon doesn't need to hear all this. He's a highly trained professional."[/b]

Despite his appearance as a simple scientist, Gordon Freeman handles weapons to perfection, thanks to the time he spent in the "Hazard Course".
The weapons are very numerous and varied, classic or experimental, and even a few of alien origin...
Here's the full list of weapons:

Crowbar
Pistol
Shotgun
SMG or AR
Revolver
Crossbow
Rocket Launcher
Grenade
Tripmine
C4
Snark
Hivehand
Gauss Gun
Gluon Gun

[b]"Those new suits can be tricky. Please proceed to the next area."[/b]

Hazard Course is Black Mesa's training space for H.E.V suit users.
This is the one and only tutorial present in Half-Life, made to familiarize yourself with the game's mechanics.

[b]"Hey, did you hear something?"[/b]

The music and sounds in Half-Life are of high quality.
They were composed by Kelly Bailey.
Each important moment in the game has its own music, sometimes gloomy, sometimes epic.
"Hazardous Environments", the Valve Theme, which gives you chills during the fight on the edge of the cliff in "Surface Tension"...

All human characters are voiced, and each monster has its own sounds.
It's easy to know which enemy to face next without even seeing it.
Every sound accentuate the science fiction touch and the player's immersion.
The voice of the H.E.V. Suit gives valuable information on the environment, health status or quantity of ammunition.

[b]"You sure we're going the right way?"[/b]

The graphics of Half-Life are sumptuous for its time, thanks to the GoldSrc engine.
The game became more beautiful and detailed when it was (re)released on Steam.
The settings are particularly immersive and varied.

[b]"Didn't want to die alone anyway."[/b]

In addition to its extraordinary single-player campaign, 
Half-Life has a classic multiplayer deathmatch mode.
The fights are fun, dynamic and brutal, 
thanks to the large quantity weapons available to players.
In addition to that, 
there's a plethoric choice of 18 maps and they're different enough to renew the gaming experience.

[b]"Catch me later, I'll buy you a beer."[/b]

2023 marks the 25th anniversary of Half-Life, which Valve celebrated with a content-rich update.
First of all, the main menu of the game has been replaced by that of the WON version: it is the original menu from 1998.
The original Valve intro is also restored.

It finally brings Half-Life Uplink to Steam, which we've been waiting for so long.
Half-Life Uplink is a unique Half-Life demo, released in early 1999.
This level never appeared in the original game, it was a standalone only.

Four new multiplayer maps are added, and three from the Half-Life: Further Data additional content CD.

Four new multiplayer skins are added, including Ivan The Space Biker and Proto-Barney, from the 1997 Alpha Version

[b]"Another important species revealed in action."[/b]

In addition to being an exceptional game, Half-Life gave birth to a large number of cult multiplayer FPS franchises:
Day of Defeat, Team Fortress, and Counter-Strike.

[b]"I predicted all of this, you know. All of it!"[/b]

Half-Life is a remarkably effective FPS.
How can we not praise such a masterpiece?
This video game monument is timeless.
There is clearly a before and after Half-Life.
Every gamer must own it.

Alright. Half Life [25th Anniversary Update] is done and dusted. Freeman Hired Awaiting Assignment. Anyway, everyone has had 25 years to learn about and/or play Half Life, so I won’t go into great depth regarding the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3112680756

I can however assert that it still holds up immaculately today. Does it show its age? Of course. Although I'd argue that considering its age, it's still a pretty stunning looking game. Does it actually add to the game’s charm? Definitely. Plus, it’s a literal piece of gaming history, and funny enough, the gameplay is still better than a lot of modern shooters.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3113427468

I don’t remember enough of my previous playthroughs to definitively discuss how the recent (as of the time of this writing) update changes things, but I did feel like parts of the level design here and there had been tweaked. I also note that it ran immaculately on the Steam Deck, which of course it should, being as how Valve is the creator of both.

Is there still some wonk? Yes. Ladders still aren’t your friends. Some of the platforming I still consider to be a hassle. The final boss fight is still kinda meh IMO.

But, beyond those minor complaints, as mentioned before, this game holds up remarkably well, and I feel like you owe it to yourself to play it again, or for the first time, before it truly does age beyond what people are mostly willing to accept. If that’s actually possible, which I’m not certain of since 25 years did nothing to squash its viability.

One further note about Steam Deck play. It was incredibly battery friendly. I was getting close to the full six hours on default settings. Which was maybe the biggest surprise of all.

And as an interesting side note: while Valve is a massive powerhouse these days despite maintaining what would be considered a modest staff, Half Life released while Valve was still a completely Indie studio, with Sierra Entertainment being their publisher. Funny how, in a very real sense, Valve has never forgotten their modest beginnings despite Steam being an outrageous success.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3113566770

Half Life was free recently in honor of the 25th Anniversary, but if you missed it and somehow don’t own it, it’s like 99 cents during every major Steam Sale. Play it and enjoy a timeless (so far) piece of gaming history.

Really glad I finally played this classic. Now I understand why people rave about it and fully agree that for a linear shooter adventure, there are not many (if any) games in the recent years which compare to the silky smooth flow of the game. Playing this after watching the mini documentary made certain aspects of the game sink in even more (ie. when the devs said they aimed to have some form of event/action every 3-5 seconds). If you focus on the content, the level design, the flow, the pacing of platformer vs shooting vs puzzle solving and the deeper aspects of game design, it is a master piece (except for Xen). 

All that praise aside, be ready for a few annoyances (not game breaking but a wee-bit annoying and just a product of the time the game was made) such as rather finicky jump controls (especially on Xen), helicopters with seemingly x-ray vision picking you off in tunnels, some of the platforming sections are a touch tedious/annoying. I repeat, these are nitpicks. 

Overall, glad I played this classic and would highly recommend it to anyone ESPECIALLY if you are into game design and/or a game director. A lot can still be learned from this game.

this is a game that i had first started playing over a year ago at the recommendation of some friends who thought i'd like the lore (i'm a big fan of portal's story so it's almost a disservice not to have gone through this series yet anyways), getting only about a quarter of the way through, and just now i went back and replayed through the whole thing to completion.

to me, half-life is a game that excels mostly in combat variety and environmental storytelling. you amass a large arsenal of different weapons through this game and the maps feature unique ways of taking out threats which always keeps things interesting (whether those methods are intentional or not lol).

while the game lacks explicit explanations about what's going on and has sparse dialogue, it tells a fascinating story mostly through the level design alone. [spoiler] i found it really cool how you could see fights breaking out between marines and xen aliens in a TON of different areas. it went a long way in helping the world and the conflict feel alive, while also allowing for strategic opportunities where you could balance out the conflict from the sidelines to ensure both sides go down at once! every area in the game looks strikingly unique, from the sprawling black mesa facilities to the sandy canyons of the surface to the grotesque and abstract structures of xen. [/spoiler]  

however, it is important to recognize that this game was made over 25 years ago now, and shows its age in its core design. the variety is really the only thing that the combat has going for it, as the enemies have pretty funky ai that doesn't really know how to react if you play in any way that isn't just rushing in guns blazing. the game also feels reliant on the player saving and loading multiple times over to learn enemy spawns and create the best outcome. for every scenario where you can identify a set of enemies from a distance and dispatch them strategically, there is another scenario where an alien spawns in on a bridge and breaks it, making you fall with it in a panic while you're being pummeled to death, or where an additional wave of enemies shows up by surprise and wipes you out while you're distracted by the first. perhaps these events exist to balance out the enemies not knowing how to react when you're the one who's approaching, which is when their ai is most able to be abused, but it is still frustrating nonetheless.

overall, half-life is at most a fun, classic game where you're a cool dude in a suit with an assortment of powerful weapons, set out to stop the alien invasion that you started. as you go, you stun the world around you by being the sole person who doesn't break out into dance or decide to blow themselves and their squad to smoldering smithereens with a hand grenade when they get damaged.  and at the very least, half-life is a fascinating time capsule into the state of games at the time of its creation, highlighting where things once were and how much they've progressed over the quarter of a century. whether you like it or not, its influence continues to run deep, and it's something you can really see around you after playing through it. also of course got valve started so this game's awesome for that alone

Black Mesa: where hazard suits are stylish and headcrabs are fashion faux pas

Gordon Freeman's hazard suit is the epitome of workplace fashion. Who needs a tailored suit when you can rock the hazardous look?

Black Mesa is the place to be if you're a scientist looking to advance your career. Just ignore the resonance cascade on your way to the coffee machine – nothing to see here.

Commuting between dimensions can be a hassle. One moment you're sipping coffee in the office lounge, and the next, you're battling alien invaders. Who knew the morning rush hour could get this intense?

Apparently, getting a Ph.D. in theoretical physics makes you the universe's target for alien invasions. Note to self: reconsider career choices.

Gordon Freeman has a severe case of silent protagonist syndrome. I mean, he's saving the world, but can't he spare a word or two? Maybe a "How's it going, headcrab?" would be nice.

In conclusion, Half-Life is the workplace simulation we never knew we needed. It's a hazardous fashion show, a lesson in theoretical physics, and a crowbar-wielding adventure all rolled into one. Gordon Freeman, you stylish, silent hero – may your hazard suit stay fashionable, and may the resonance cascade always keep things interesting.

Half-Life: My god, what are you doing?

Valve is the undisputed master of the subtle shift. Paradigm adjustments to the current trends of the gaming world and always having some level of a hand involved, even when most people are just writing them off because we haven't seen a new game in a decade. They have the same energy as Carmack, except spread out through an entire cabal of goons. But they're always there in some capacity, even when you don't see them. It was Newell's team that took DOOM from DOS to Windows, and made it a monolith that's stood to this day. They're the ones to revolutionize the 3D Gaming Industry two separate times in a six year span, and make an online gaming platform so nuke proof that almost two decades later, there's no real competition and Epic can't sue their way out of it. And even when we think they're done, out pops another new thing.

All of that really starts with Half-Life. This is not simply a "revolutionary" game, this is a cornerstone. This is a foundational brick in the wider walls of modern gaming. This shook everything from simple graphical advancements and gameplay technology to the way other games structure their story, pace themselves and reveal the wider petals of the plot. Every game for a decade copied Half Life, whether openly or otherwise and none of them were able to fully capture the magic. The only person to come close was Bungie, and even they knew the winning move was not to play. Merely adopt and improve. 

It's all little details effortlessly thrown in, from the various Chekhov's Guns of the G-Man, the overarching plot culminating in a tram ride in the abyss and the various hints along the way. You're not a divine super soldier, you're a 27 year old theoretical physicist who just so happened to be wearing his suit when he ripped a hole through time and space. You're another pawn on a chessboard too high for you to see the pattern of, and all you can do is watch. Watch, and accidentally kill yourself with snarks again because you forgot how fast they bounce around a small room.

I could wax poetic about Half Life's virtues for hours, but I won't. You know it's fantastic already. I'll instead leave this review with a perfect summation of this game and Valve as a whole. When this game came out, the current reigning champ of graphics and storytelling was Unreal by Epic Games. 8 months later, Epic had a dev team push out the Return to Na Pali expansion, which added a centralized story and various "improvements" that feel like a pallid attempt to catch up to Valve. And then they would do Unreal 2. And while working on the groundwork for another game, Valve would oh-so-casually release Half Life 2. And then suddenly all further Unreal games were merely tournament shooters. 

Take the hint, Sweeney.

I just beat this game for the first time in the year of our lord (Gabe Newell) 2023. Needless to say, the hype was warranted with this game.  Even 25 years after launch, I was greatly impressed by the ambience and polish despite the limitations of the time. 
Everything from the flat repeating textures, to the strange reverberations of your footsteps off different materials, to the npcs sounding like they're talking through walkie talkies takes you into the gritty, bleak setting of the game.
Imagine my surprise when, instead of a hour or two long game like the first portal, I found myself plunged into a 11 hour experience. Don't be fooled, this game is TOUGH! I was constantly at low health, so the frequent health stations and pickups were a life saver.
My only complaint would be with the final boss being a bit clunky and unclear as to what to do. Might've been just me, but even coming off the self-directed nature of the rest of the game, I found myself a bit confused and frustrated during the boss.
Its clear to see how many games have taken inspiration from the look and feel of this classic. While I don't feel this game is for everyone, its easy to see why many regard this as one of the best games of all time.

Half-Life is an amazing classic experience that I would recommend anyone to try out. There is so much good about the Half-Life game. The mechanics, challenges, and puzzles you encounter throughout the game keep you engaged, entertained, and immersed in the world of Black Messa. The visuals, while of course not realistic, are still pleasing and nice in spite of such.

If there HAD to be something to criticise about the game, some of the movement controls (especially jumping) can take a short while to get used to. But with time you'll be able to grasp it. There are also "some" visual bugs I encountered but they were extremely insignificant and depending on how you're playing, you may not even encounter them at all. 

So overall, Half-Life is an iconic, enjoyable, engaging, entertaining, and fascinating game that I would recommend nearly everyone to play. If there was a game that I would confidentially give a 10/10, this would be one of them.

Really enjoying the experience, it seems I've been missing out on this game.
There's many cases where I say, "This is a good place to save and continue later" and then just go on progressing and saving again for another hour without even feeling it. 
Half life is giving me a really nostalgic feeling of old school games . And also I feel for the first time in a while, I'm actually playing a game that isn't playing itself for me, or that it is backseating me.

There's no pointers to the goal, no map, no quest line, no popups everywhere, just raw gaming time, and I gotta say, it feels so much greater playing and advancing this way. I died a lot, I learned form my experience, 
 and then I figured out the way forward. 

Loved the show, don't tell, approach of half life as well.
You notice little hints and details in the environment that allow you to figure out what to do. It was kind of a shock how used to being shown a pointer to where to go I've been. It feels more rewarding to figure out the puzzles and to advance in your own accord. I felt more in control and immersed, and continuing the mission was accompanied with great storytelling. So great. It's miles better from getting solution to your situation spelled out for you.

Really recommend this game to anyone who has yet to try it, looking forward to finish it and continue on to the sequels <3

- 2 g dried marjoram
- 1 g ground coriander
- 1 g grated nutmeg
- 1 g ground cardamom
- Pork casings for stuffing
- Kitchen twine

Instructions:
1. Cut the beef and pork into small pieces and pass them through a meat grinder with a coarse plate.
2. Place the ground meat in a large bowl and add all the spices (curing salt, pepper, paprika, garlic powder, ginger powder, marjoram, coriander, nutmeg, and cardamom). Mix well until the spices are evenly distributed.
3. Cover the meat mixture and let it rest in the refrigerator for at least 24 hours to allow the flavors to develop.
4. Thoroughly clean the pork casings and soak them in cold water to soften.
5. Remove the meat mixture from the refrigerator and knead it again to ensure proper blending.
6. Stuff the meat mixture into the prepared pork casings, ensuring there are no air pockets and that the casings are evenly filled.
7. Cut the filled casings into approximately 10 cm long pieces and tie the ends with kitchen twine.
8. Hang the Landjäger sausages in a cool place to dry for about 2-3 weeks. The ideal temperature is around 15-18 degrees Celsius.
9. After the drying period, the Landjäger sausages are ready to be consumed. They can be enjoyed raw or lightly pan-fried.

Note: When making sausage, it is important to maintain proper hygiene. Ensure all utensils are thoroughly cleaned, and use fresh meat. It is also recommended to familiarize yourself with basic sausage-making principles and consider employing specific sausage-making techniques.



German:

Selbstgemachte Landjäger Wurst

Zutaten:
- 500 g Rindfleisch
- 500 g Schweinefleisch
- 20 g Nitritpökelsalz
- 5 g Pfeffer, grob gemahlen
- 5 g Paprika, edelsüß
- 3 g Knoblauchpulver
- 2 g Ingwerpulver
- 2 g Majoran, getrocknet
- 1 g Koriander, gemahlen
- 1 g Muskatnuss, gerieben
- 1 g Kardamom, gemahlen
- Schweinedärme zum Abfüllen
- Küchengarn

Zubereitung:
1. Das Rind- und Schweinefleisch in kleine Stücke schneiden und anschließend durch den Fleischwolf mit grober Scheibe drehen.
2. Das gewolfte Fleisch in eine große Schüssel geben und alle Gewürze (Nitritpökelsalz, Pfeffer, Paprika, Knoblauchpulver, Ingwerpulver, Majoran, Koriander, Muskatnuss und Kardamom) hinzufügen. Gut vermengen, bis die Gewürze gleichmäßig verteilt sind.
3. Die Fleischmasse abgedeckt für mindestens 24 Stunden im Kühlschrank ruhen lassen, damit sich die Aromen entfalten können.
4. Die Schweinedärme gründlich reinigen und in kaltem Wasser einweichen, um sie geschmeidig zu machen.
5. Die Fleischmasse aus dem Kühlschrank nehmen und erneut gut durchkneten.
6. Nun den Fleischteig in die vorbereiteten Schweinedärme füllen. Dabei darauf achten, dass keine Luftblasen entstehen und der Darm gut gefüllt ist.
7. Die gefüllten Därme in etwa 10 cm lange Stücke schneiden und die Enden mit Küchengarn verschließen.
8. Die Landjäger für ca. 2-3 Wochen an einem kühlen Ort zum Trocknen aufhängen. Die ideale Temperatur liegt bei etwa 15-18 Grad Celsius.
9. Nach der Trocknungszeit sind die Landjäger bereit zum Verzehr. Sie können roh gegessen werden oder kurz in einer Pfanne gebraten werden.

Hinweis: Bei der Herstellung von Wurst ist es wichtig, auf hygienische Standards zu achten. Sämtliche Utensilien sollten gründlich gereinigt und das Fleisch frisch sein. Es empfiehlt sich außerdem, sich mit den Grundlagen der Wurstherstellung vertraut zu machen und gegebenenfalls auf spezielle Wurstherstellungstechniken zurückzugreifen.


Chinese:

自制兰德亚格香肠

材料：
- 500克牛肉
- 500克猪肉
- 20克食盐（亚硝酸盐食盐）
- 5克粗磨黑胡椒
- 5克甜辣椒粉
- 3克大蒜粉
- 2克姜粉
- 2克干马郁兰
- 1克芫荽粉
- 1克磨碎肉豆蔻
- 1克磨碎草果
- 猪肠衣（用于填充）
- 厨房绳

制作方法：
1. 将牛肉和猪肉切成小块，然后通过带有粗孔板的绞肉机绞碎。
2. 将绞碎的肉放入一个大碗中，加入所有的香料（食盐、黑胡椒、甜辣椒粉、大蒜粉、姜粉、马郁兰、芫荽粉、肉豆蔻和草果）。充分搅拌，使香料均匀分布。
3. 盖上碗，放入冰箱中静置至少24小时，使香味融合。
4. 彻底清洁猪肠衣，并将其浸泡在冷水中软化。
5. 从冰箱中取出肉馅，再次揉捏均匀。
6. 将肉馅填入准备好的猪肠衣中，确保没有气泡并且填充均匀。
7. 将填充好的猪肠衣切成约10厘米长的小段，用厨房绳扎紧两端。
8. 将兰德亚格香肠挂在凉爽的地方晾干约2-3周，理想温度为摄氏15-18度。
9. 干燥期结束后，兰德亚格香肠即可食用。可以生食或轻微煎炒。

注意：制作香肠时，保持良好的卫生非常重要。确保所有器具彻底清洁，并使用新鲜的肉类。还建议熟悉基本的制香肠原则，并考虑采用特定的制香肠技巧。

It's Half-Life, the revolutionary "thinking man's" FPS game that shaked up the gaming world.

When it came out, it was incredibly immersive, with a connected world, a story told not thru cut-scenes but by player's participation, the ground-breaking "3D sound", puzzle-like gameplay and, for the time, advanced AI, physics and graphics.

It also came with a MP part, which was outshined  by the free mod "Counter-Strike", nonetheless it was an enjoyable attachment, as well as the ability to create mods, which the community put good use of.

What we have here is a free update of the classic game that adds support for higher resolutions, wide-screen aspect ratio and numerous other "under the hood" improvements which will surely benefit the existing modding scene.

For a limited time, it was free to grab for all Steam users, but even at the current price, it's worth it, as it's one of the best FPS, and generally speaking, games ever made.

This is an unpopular opinion I believe, but I don't think [b]Half-Life[/b] is that good. I just don't see it as a masterpiece everyone claims it to be. I beat it for the first time earlier this year and I wasn't impressed. I played it again for 25th anniversary, and my opinion hasn't changed very much.

I think it's consistently frustrating - there's a lot of poor enemy placements, like headcrabs in vents early on. Are they supposed to be scary? I found them more annoying than anything. Or [url=https://i.imgur.com/JWhXYQI.jpg]when you see a medical terminal[/url], and then [url=https://i.imgur.com/1BLqe6e.jpg]an enemy[/url] spawns behind you. Or cheap moments like [url=https://i.imgur.com/h2Dovhi.jpg]this sniper[/url] that isn't very obvious. The game baits you with a health pickup, only to deliver a middle finger. Or [url=https://i.imgur.com/zQGbQLh.jpg]or this normal looking cracked wall texture[/url]? Except [url=https://i.imgur.com/FWQ7RBM.jpg]it's not and will rain you with bricks[/url] (doesn't do a lot of damage, but still kind of annoying). Or [url=https://i.imgur.com/pYkUaxp.jpg]this structure[/url] full of teleports? They may teleport you forward, or towards bonuses... or straight up cheap death. How generous.

I could go on, but I hope I won't have to list more examples. I just don't think [b]Half-Life[/b] holds up all that well. Even physics aren't very good, when you have a bunch of platforming and you're awfully slippery, falling to your death is not uncommon. Air mobility is poor, and ladders are janky as hell. You have to realize that the game may not be so kind to first time players... or even second time players in my case.

So... why recommend anyway, despite it supposedly not being all that great? Well, it IS one of THE games of all time. You should check it out and make your own judgement. You may find this game to hold up just fine, or find it to be an infuriating piece of garbage. And it's not without merit - it's immersive, while there are some pacing issues, it's mostly pretty good - there are almost no cutscenes to stop you and you can ignore NPCs if you know what to do already. Everything happens in real time. The gunplay is also decent. There must be a reason why it's so beloved. It may not be my cup of tea, but it's still an interesting piece of gaming history. [b]Half-Life 2[/b] is way better though, haha.

It's a fun game. I think the gameplay has aged quite well, and although it's simple compared to modern titles, it has a "be smart, hit or die" vibe that I like, especially on the hardest difficulty where enemies deal high damage, and insta-kill weapons are a resource to manage. Even on the highest difficulty setting, enemies never turn into bullet sponges. You always have a weapon or combination of weapons that efficiently and satisfactorily kills a certain enemy quite well.

Despite the enjoyable gameplay, I find the level design to be labyrinthine and confusing. Even seemingly straightforward maps appear complicated due to their nonsensical design. The levels are made to position enemies in a way that allows players to either avoid or kill them from several angles. While this design has its merits, I found myself having to backtrack multiple times to figure out where I am supposed to go.

The rail section was really, really annoying. I got stuck because I was unaware that shooting the signs changed the direction (had to google that up). This section has a level design that consists of riding the train and facing intermittent ambushes. It becomes frustrating as every open space forces you to stop the train and clear the area before continuing, or risk an easy death. I was happy when this gameplay loop ended.

Another less enjoyable section is Xen. While I like its aesthetics (it really looks pretty alien), the gameplay mostly involves avoiding annoying enemies by bhopping. Unless you've saved a lot of ammo, you'll most likely look for scraps in hidden corners. As for the final boss, it's simple and boring. Fortunately, its attack pattern is easy to dodge, and the only concern is the green teleporting balls, but you can hide behind spikes/walls, that way you avoid teleportation. To beat the boss, you just need to shoot the crystals and then keep spamming the crossbow until it dies. I'm glad for the lack of difficulty in this boss battle because I think it would have been quite frustrating to defeat a hard/complex boss with so little ammo.

It has a pretty fun campaign being something similar to how I played Metroid Prime being mostly a linear adventure FPS with few backtracking here and there which is easy to get engaged with. The slippery controls took a real good while to get used to, especially considering I don’t really like using mouse and keyboard, but still tolerable for the most part. My biggest surprise was how narratively light it was being more so dressing in the background besides the long introduction at the start. Not that I mind, since the overall experience made the light narrative work well with essentially getting the player into the game as much as possible and just having the core gameplay of making mad dash through the lab as fun as it can be. Great game, no doubt about it, but I do have some warnings for anyone that's looking to buy. Being an old game, there are some obvious issues with it. The movement is a bit clunky at times, and there are points where something will randomly insta-kill you with no explanation, and I couldn't even tell you what it was after going back over it a dozen times. Some of the puzzles can get a bit tedious at times, since there is very little explanation. However, for a game made before the turn of the century, it is fantastic. The graphics look way better than they should for a game that preceded even Halo, the fighting is clean and fun, and the overall mechanics are years ahead of its time. Overall, despite getting annoyed with it at times, I stayed glued to my seat for five hours at a time. It has more than earned its place among the classics, and I highly recommend it.

November 19, 1998, marked the detonation of Half-Life onto the gaming scene—a brainchild of the dynamic duo, Gabe Newell and Mike Harrington, steering the ship at Valve Corporation. Powered by the tweaked Quake engine, baptized as the GoldSrc engine, this marvel wasn't merely a game; it was the forge where Valve's future triumphs were hammered into existence.

This technological beast didn't just propel the narrative of Half-Life; it laid down the blueprints for gaming's tomorrow, with physics and AI that seemed to have a mind of its own. The GoldSrc engine didn't just raise the bar; it launched it into orbit.

Half-Life wasn't content with being just a game; it was a manifesto for storytelling and technology, reshaping the FPS genre and bulldozing through it, leaving a trail of innovation that echoes through the halls of game development. Valve wasn't just a company; it became a powerhouse, a force to be reckoned with.

November 19, 1998—mark it as a milestone, a celestial event in gaming's timeline. It wasn't just a release date; it was the birth of a legacy, an influence that still courses through the veins of game development, reminding us all that once upon a time, Half-Life changed the game.

### The Story of Half-Life

In the scientific chaos of Black Mesa, enter Gordon Freeman—not your average theoretical physicist but a one-man wrecking crew against interdimensional havoc. The experiment to open a portal to another dimension? Let's just say it didn't go as planned, unleashing a cosmic catastrophe that makes Monday mornings seem like a cakewalk.

No cutscenes here; the Half-Life saga unfolds in real-time chaos, immersing players in an unpredictable plot. Gordon battles aliens and military goons, all while the mysterious G-Man lurks in the shadows, overseeing like a cosmic supervisor with a questionable agenda.

As Gordon, you're not just surviving—you're thriving amidst government conspiracies and the aftermath of a scientific oopsie. The Black Ops join the party, and the story dives into the consequences of playing with portals. From underground labs to the alien abyss of Xen, Gordon's journey is a rollercoaster of survival, conspiracy, and the fallout of unchecked experiments.

And let's not forget our hero, Gordon Freeman—the silent protagonist with a PhD in kicking alien butt, facing the Nihilanth, the puppet master behind the invasion.

### The Weapons of Half-Life

In the chaotic dance of survival, Gordon Freeman wields a diverse arsenal in Half-Life, each weapon a symphony of destruction:

1. **Crowbar:** A symbol of resourcefulness, Gordon's trusty melee companion. When brains meet brawn, it's crowbar time.
2. **Glock 17:** The first firearm encountered, a reliable semi-auto lifeline in the struggle for survival. One squeeze, one less obstacle. Okay maybe more like two three or four or five.
3. **MP5 Submachine Gun:** With a grenade launcher in tow, this bad boy offers versatility in enemy dispatch. It's not just a gun; it's a statement.
4. **SPAS-12 Shotgun:** When things get up close and personal, the SPAS-12 delivers a symphony of devastation. Close quarters, meet firepower.
5. **Crossbow:** Silent, deadly, and perfect for those long-range rendezvous. A whisper in the dark, and enemies fall.
6. **Tau Cannon:** Experimental energy unleashed. When the Tau Cannon sings, enemies dance in its destructive melody.
7. **Gluon Gun:** Emitting a devastating energy beam, this experimental piece is the stuff of enemy nightmares. When subtlety isn't your style.
8. **Hivehand:** Alien sophistication at its finest. Homing organic projectiles, because regular ammo is too mainstream.
9. **Satchel Charges:** Deployable chaos. When a strategic touch of destruction is on the menu, satchel charges deliver.
10. **RPG:** When the going gets tough, the RPG gets going. Perfect for those adversaries who don't take a hint.
11. **Gauss Gun:** The game-changer. Launching high-velocity projectiles, it's the trump card in later stages. When you need to redefine the battlefield.

### The Enemies of Half-Life

1. **Headcrab:** Small terrors that latch onto your noggin, turning you into a puppet for their undead puppet show. Cute, right?
2. **Zombie:** The result of a Headcrab's twisted makeover—slow, relentless, and utterly unimpressed by your survival skills.
3. **Vortigaunt:** Alien shockers with a penchant for zapping your hopes and dreams. Hostile at first, but hey, they're just misunderstood, right?
4. **Houndeye:** Dog days are over. Now meet the dog-like aliens emitting sonic chaos because tranquility is overrated.
5. **Bullsquid:** Acid-spitting alien rage machines, proving that in the extraterrestrial beauty pageant, they win the "Most Likely to Ruin Your Day" category.
6. **Ichthyosaur:** Aquatic nightmares with a taste for human sushi. Enjoy the swim, just beware of the toothy welcome party.
7. **Black Ops:** Government's finest with a mission to cover up their mess. Advanced weaponry meets advanced levels of denial.
8. **Gargantua:** Massive, flame-throwing nightmares straight out of military daycare. Because nothing says "containment" like a walking inferno.
9. **Nihilanth:** The grand finale, an extradimensional overlord with a passion for invasion. Think of it as the alien maestro, conducting your demise.
10. **Hazardous Environment Combat Unit (HECU):** Military might gone mad. Because when facing alien threats, you definitely want these guys on your side, right? (Spoiler: You don't.)

### Multiplayer

Half-Life Deathmatch, a side venture in the Half-Life universe, proved to be a surprise hit, injecting a competitive spark into the game's core. Developed alongside the single-player campaign, this mode flexed the game's mechanics in a player-versus-player showdown, seamlessly integrating the diverse arsenal from the solo journey into intense, fast-paced battles.

Sure, Deathmatch had its teething problems, with a few weapons hogging the spotlight more than others. Yet, despite the balancing act, it became a late '90s and mid-2000s sensation, birthing one of gaming's most devoted mapping communities. Players and modders crafted a plethora of custom maps, injecting longevity into the game and turning Deathmatch into a canvas of creativity.

What makes Half-Life Deathmatch endure isn't just the competition—it's the community. A legion of players and modders kept the flame alive, churning out custom content that turned multiplayer into a dynamic, ever-evolving experience. The legacy of Half-Life Deathmatch isn't just in the fragging; it's in the camaraderie, the dedication, and the endless creativity that breathed life into virtual battlefields for years.

Half Life is the best N64 game I've ever played. It has skeletons in its animation budget and bullet decals and ennemies that run around like they don't want to die. What a revolutionary title. But what's it about? Well, Half Life is about a regular guy working at a giant government complex in the middle of the desert, named Gordon Freeman. The place he works at is called Black Mesa and your mom is a hoe.

But then, you slam the space rock into the mega laser and time and space breaks loose. Everyone dies, there's blood everywhere. And transdimentional creatures are turning your coworkers into zombies. So you fight your way to the surface, hoping the military has a solution for this whole mess and you find out they do have a solution... Mass Scientific Genocide.
I feel like an idiot explaining the plot of a game like half life. It's so ingrained into gaming culture what half life was, what half life meant.  But, being that this is a review. I feel forced to lay down the basics, at least. Which is appropriate, because laying down the basics is exactly what Half Life does. While playing half life, without being told anything, you feel like you're being taught about the basics of game desing. 

And it's fair to say that its appraoch to narrative is still quite revolutionary. How many story rich games released in the past 10 years without cutscenes. Try naming one, I'll wait! Half life is special in that it offers one long unbroken narrative. Where you control the character at the begining of the story, and you don't stop doing so until the credits roll. It felt game changing at the time, and it's still impressive to this day.

Once, again, I feel like a dumbass explaining this shit. Like, if you haven't played half life, you're probably looking at this, not getting what makes it special. Because, from a modern lense, it just looks like any regular shooter. But, that's exactly what makes it special. The fact that it looks and feels like a standard game is mostly explained by the fact that modern gaming was built on the shoulders of it.

It elevated the bar so greatly that, 25 years later, it's still a rather fresh experience. It's weird that the default speed is running, and pressing shift makes you walk, but other than that,  Half Life very much manages to feel modern in a way few 90s games can. What most stands out is the heavy reliance on setpieces and scripted sequences. Characters talking to you and interacting with the environment. Half Life is so full of clever moments. You often feel like the devs are watching you play, thinking how best to mess with you this time.

There's flow and coherence to half life. Still, it's an old game and it can be pretty unfair and janky. The speed of the game can make it feel a bit slippery and the plot beyond its initial setup, is just a random set of NPCs telling why you're moving forward trough these linear corridors. But hey, Half Life is the grandfather of storytelling in action games. It's always been old, in a way. It made everyone realise just how early in the life of gaming we still live. If we don't all die of global warming within the next 20 years. We can always look back at half life, to try and understand what made the medium so special to begin with.

One thing that's weird is that 25 years later the game is still getting patches, fixing animation syncing issues like this scientist being grabbed by the Tentacule. You're probably surprised looking at this footage, because you've gotten so acclimated to it looking wrong but yeah. It took 25 years, but someone at valve fixed that. It's funny because the game is still really, really buggy and messy, in a lot of ways.

One issue I encountered is this event where you're forced to take damage. They try to counter that fact by placing medpacks there, but, as you can see. It's not fucking working. The problem is that the closest med station is literally 5 minutes and one flaming Tentacule spelunking expedition ago and I used it all up anyway. I was forced to reload to a manual save. Which I was lucky to have. Because, otherwise I would've had to redo the whole chapter. 

There's also this elevator that causes you to take damage, for some reason. Still, masterpiece masterpiece, this game is a masterpiece. So, maybe, from a modern lense, Half Life can seem pretty quaint. Some of the levels, like Xen and the waste processing plant, are just really bad. They're hard to navigate and they fail to feel like functional, real places. Still, even at its weakest, Half Life is still more creative than most games will allow themselves to be.

In short, Half Life is a golden example of brilliant game desing. It was made on dinosaurs by a bunch of quake modders helmed by two guys who used to work at microsoft and it rehinvented what it meant to make video games. It served as a guideline to what video games had to be from now on and, to this day, there is still a lot that could be learned from half life.

Its music is wonderfully atmospheric and it always manages to fit the mood perfectly. I honestly don't know what else to gush about. Half Life is just so goddamn wonderful.

I give half Life a flawed but beautiful 119 out of 124. Something this brilliant needs to be played to understand how to make games. Sentence that makes sense and concludes the video. Brain brain brain. I am a talking brain. I use my appendages to interact with the glyph device and the monolith formulates it into text on the display board. How magical is the whole human experience? The answer is not magical at all. Which is what makes it so magical to begin with.

This game still has a lot of stuff going for it. 1998 first person shooter. In that frame of reference, this game is a marvel. You got rocket launchers, crazy made-up physics guns, secondary fire options that feel very cool when you know how to use them, and a story that is easy to understand and leads to a lot of potential rabbit holes. 

My only issue with games like these is I never know how difficult the game is supposed to be. I picked medium and the encounters feel quite fair most of the time. The problem is the game increasingly require more and more platforming of you as the levels go on. This is something the game does not excel at. The platforming feels exacting and unfun. I grew on up Nintendo platformers and find any puzzles or obstacles requiring jumping dexterity in the game to be a real drag. The final boss battle is marred for me because of this. When the game is focusing on FPS action and novelty, which is most of the time, that is when it shines. 

The puzzles that require navigation skills and not exact jumps are quite good. The weapons are thought out, and paced quite well. The music honestly pretty good when they have it. I would still recommend this game if you wanna check out an old-school FPS that probably inspired a lot of people.
