[h3] 25th Anniversary Update [/h3]
Seven maps, weapon balancing, and Steam networking revitalized the Deathmatch playerbase. Console commands are no longer required to fix widescreen FOV and to disable texture filtering. The original Quake-style view tilt, main menu art, and Valve intro are restored.

The HUD is now scaled with high resolutions, and low input latency is a welcome addition, especially for Counter-Strike. Increased engine limitations (and Counter-Strike func_vehicle) will allow map and mod creators to make amazing stuff. The last things I wish for are an internal resolution scaler, texture-animated water for OpenGL, and dynamic lighting à la Nightdive.

A Timeless Classic That Defines the Genre

Half-Life is a game that stands the test of time, and its presence on Steam is a testament to its enduring greatness. As soon as you become Gordon Freeman, you get immediately immersed in a world of seamlessly blended storytelling, innovative gameplay mechanics, and unmatched immersion. The narrative naturally unfolds as you navigate the Black Mesa Research Facility, unraveling a mysterious and captivating story that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The absence of cutscenes enhances the immersive experience, allowing the player to stay fully engaged in the unfolding events. The attention to detail in the environmental storytelling is remarkable, making every corner of Black Mesa feel alive and consequential.

Gameplay-wise, Half-Life was groundbreaking in its time and continues to be a benchmark for the first-person shooter genre. The introduction of the HEV suit, with its iconic voice prompts, adds a layer of strategy to combat, and the arsenal of weapons is diverse and satisfying to use. The introduction of the gravity gun in later iterations only adds to the already stellar gameplay mechanics, providing a unique twist to the traditional FPS formula. What sets Half-Life apart is its commitment to innovation. The game introduces players to new concepts and challenges at a steady pace, keeping the experience fresh and exciting from start to finish. The level design strikes a perfect balance between challenging puzzles and intense firefights. The variety in environments, from the sterile labs to the eerie Xen dimension, showcases the developers' creativity and ability to craft a diverse and cohesive gaming experience.

The modding community surrounding Half-Life has also contributed to its longevity. With an overload of user-created content on Steam, the game continually evolves and offers new experiences to veteran players and those discovering it for the first time. In terms of visuals, while the graphics may not be cutting-edge by today's standards, the art direction has a timeless quality. The atmosphere created by the lighting, sound design, and environmental details still holds up, creating a mood that few games have been able to replicate. In conclusion, Half-Life is more than just a game; it's a milestone in the history of video games. Its influence gets felt in countless titles that followed, and its presence on Steam ensures that a new generation of gamers can experience the magic that captivated players when it was first released. If you haven't played Half-Life, it's not just a game; it's an essential piece of gaming history that deserves a place in every gamer's library.

Half-Life... Where do I start with this game?

Half-Life 1 was the first game in the series I got my hands on, and my favorite. Guess I'll start off with the obvious.

1. The Approach: Half-Life was unique to FPS games like DooM, Quake, and the Build Engine trilogy at the time. It took time at the start of its campaign to build the characters and the feel of Black Mesa. 
Taking two chapters (Black Mesa Inbound and Anomalous Materials.) To focus on character development, and getting the player into the world that Valve had set up for them. Like watching scientists in the distance run around, getting their work done in the iconic train ride.

2. The Gameplay: Valve wanted the player to feel like they were trapped in a scenario they couldn't control. Like they were just some guy who was in the wrong place at the wrong time. Hence why the first Headcrab you encounter is so early you don't even have the Crowbar yet.
Ahh, the Crowbar, the only melee weapon you get throughout Gordon's entire adventure through Black Mesa. This was to enhance that feeling of 'Shit's hit the fan, time to get outta here.'
Moreover, the player's health caps at 100, no higher, no lower. Again, you're not a super-soldier, just a scientist trying to survive.
And most notably at the time. Fall Damage and Reloading. Quake went full 3D. Half-Life went full realism. Reloading was such a novelty at the time, I can think of one other game that had reloading for all of its guns. Marathon.
Fall damage was also a rare thing. The Build Engine had it, but it was negligible. In Half Life, a full 3D game unlike the Build Trilogy, had fall damage make its presence known. Take Blast Pit for example. The map's mostly vertical, and you can't jump from the top floor to the bottom without tanking some large damage. Or right after that chapter in Power Up. There's a pipe before meeting the Gargantuan that can't be lived through on low health, unless the player lands on the table with the medkits.

3. The Story: You should know it by now. You are Gordon Freeman, a Theoretical Physicist working for Black Mesa. A top secret research facility in the middle of the desert in New Mexico.
One fateful day, after being late for work, Gordon begins the usual experiment using an Anti-Mass Spectrometer and a crystal specimen from Xen, the border world. But things go wrong, causing a Resonance Cascade, ripping open a portal to Xen, allowing alien creatures to spill through.
Gordon survives the Cascade itself and fights his way through the facility. Going toe to toe with both the Xen forces, and the HECU, a highly trained group of soldiers sent to kill everyone to cover up Black Mesa's existence.
Gordon finally reaches the Lambda labs, and is sent to Xen by the surviving members of the Science Team there, and slays the Nihlanth, the being holding the portal between Xen and Earth open.
Afterwards, he has an encounter with the G-Man. Whom he had been seeing since his train ride to work when this whole mess started.
Being sent to a recreation of said train. The G-Man offers Gordon a job under his employers. Gordon accepts and is sent into stasis until the events of the second game.
This approach at story through the eyes of someone in the middle of the event was something the gaming idustry had never seen before. Usually it was reading the game's manual, or through on-screen text that lore was presented.
But Valve changed that, and made the game that would shape the way FPS games were done to this very day.

That was a wall of text, but long story short, Buy Half-Life if you haven't already. It's a great game, Immersive and fun, a great experience overall. It has its negatives, (what game doesn't?) But those negatives are outweighed by the positives. Now, "Have a safe, and productive day."

The one that started it all. If you enjoy Steam, and more specifically any of Valve's games, you owe it to yourself to try this one out. It's cheap, and though it's certainly showing its age, Half-Life still holds up well. 

The game is an FPS which pioneered the concept of seamless action: the cutscenes play out in real time while you still have full control of Gordon, meaning there isn't any break in gameplay except for occasional loading pauses. These days this is common in FPS games, but when the game came out it was ground breaking.

If you play on the harder difficulty, this can also be something of a survival horror game: you have to be very careful with spending ammo, and every stray, surprise enemy poses a big threat.

Also check out Black Mesa, which is an updated remake of this.

Half-life (symbol t½) is the time required for a quantity (of substance) to reduce to half of its initial value. The term is commonly used in nuclear physics to describe how quickly unstable atoms undergo radioactive decay or how long stable atoms survive. The term is also used more generally to characterize any type of exponential (or, rarely, non-exponential) decay. For example, the medical sciences refer to the biological half-life of drugs and other chemicals in the human body. The converse of half-life (in exponential growth) is doubling time.

The original term, half-life period, dating to Ernest Rutherford's discovery of the principle in 1907, was shortened to half-life in the early 1950s.[1] Rutherford applied the principle of a radioactive element's half-life in studies of age determination of rocks by measuring the decay period of radium to lead-206.

Half-life is constant over the lifetime of an exponentially decaying quantity, and it is a characteristic unit for the exponential decay equation. The accompanying table shows the reduction of a quantity as a function of the number of half-lives elapsed.

Half-Life is a 1998 first-person shooter game that revolutionized the genre with its immersive and realistic world, where the player must think to survive. The game follows the story of Dr. Gordon Freeman, a scientist who must escape the Black Mesa Research Facility after a physics experiment gone wrong unleashes an alien invasion. The game combines action, puzzle-solving, and storytelling in a seamless way, using scripted sequences instead of cutscenes to advance the plot. The game also features a multiplayer mode that allows the player to compete against friends and enemies around the world.

Half-Life is widely regarded as one of the best and most influential games ever made, winning over 50 PC “Game of the Year” awards and selling more than nine million copies by 20081. The game was praised for its graphics, gameplay, and narrative, which set a new standard for FPS games. The game also spawned a successful franchise, including several expansion packs, sequels, mods, and a remake. Half-Life is a game that every FPS fan should play, as it offers a thrilling and unforgettable experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

The ultimate modern FPS. Engaging, immersive, fast-paced, classic shooter action. The environment uses contextual clues to guide the player along its linear path. Puzzles are intuitive and interesting. The ultimate video game power fantasy, starting with nothing but a lab coat and a crowbar and eventually fighting an inter-dimensional demon baby with energy weapons. 
I believe any developer could follow the simple concepts laid forth in Half-Life and make a great video game.
>mute protagonist who isn't a legendary hero takes part in mundane act which goes awry.
>confined in the environment, as a result of your actions, you must work with what is available to progress
>while your actions have led to chaos and conflict, allegiances, objectives, and outcomes of NPCs are in a morally gray-zone, and the only certainty is the need to escape from your environment
>reward the player's progress with interesting scenarios and powerful upgrades. equally reward and punish exploration.
You could plug this formula into any type of game, Fantasy, Sci-Fi, military, crime, etc... and you would be off to a great start. The game is a master-class in game design, and is a far better game than it's sequel. 
Varied enemies, environmental hazards, and challenging puzzles paired with fluid movement and gun play result in a game that is still fun to play in 2023.

Ah, Half-Life, the game that made scientists everywhere question their career choices. This game is like a roller-coaster ride through a dystopian world, where you're constantly running from aliens, zombies, and probably your own sanity. It's the perfect blend of heart-pounding action and mind-bending puzzles that will leave you scratching your head and wondering if you missed a PhD in theoretical physics along the way.

The graphics may not be cutting-edge by today's standards, but hey, it's like a fine wine that gets better with age. And let's not forget the iconic crowbar, the ultimate tool for both home improvement and alien extermination. Who needs a plumber when you have a trusty crowbar, right?

But let's talk about the real star of the show: Gordon Freeman, the silent hero who communicates through head nods and crowbar swings. He's like the James Bond of the scientific world, except instead of fancy gadgets, he relies on his wits and a seemingly endless supply of ammo hidden in his pockets. Seriously, where does he keep all that stuff?

Now, I must warn you, Half-Life has a reputation for leaving players hanging. It's been 25 years, and we're still waiting for that elusive third instalment. It's like the gaming equivalent of waiting for a unicorn to show up at your doorstep. But hey, who needs closure when you can replay the first two games over and over again, right?

So, if you're looking for a game that will make you question reality, make you jump out of your seat, and make you wonder why you didn't pursue a career in theoretical physics, then Half-Life is the game for you. Just don't blame me if you start seeing head-crabs in your nightmares. [b]Happy 25th Anniversary, Half-Life! [/b]

Okay, I beat the game. Here's my review.

From a graphical standpoint, this game is nothing special. (The rock texture makes my eyes hurt.) However, you can turn off texture smoothing in OpenGL mode with the new update, giving the textures a pixelated charm that I really like. The software render would be my go-to for playing this game, except for the fact that the weapon models don't show up. Huh.

Half-Life has what we today would consider a pretty standard story. You play as a scientist named Gordon Freeman (whom I have no doubt you've heard of before). He goes to work at a Texas-based science facility called Black Mesa, and is running a little late. He uses his gift of sprinting at ninety miles an hour (not part of the canon, but still in the game for some reason) to put on his fancy orange jumpsuit before heading over to the test chamber. Orange jumpsuit... test chamber... huh. Guess this game really was influential. Anyway, the crystal blows up when Gordon blasts it with a laser, and he uses his arsenal of high-tech weaponry such as crowbars and crossbows to make it out of the facility.

[spoiler] The military is sent in to contain the situation by killing everyone, so Gordon steals their machine guns to blast his way through them. Eventually, he makes it to the Lambda Complex and is told that the alien portal that was opened when the crystal blew up is being kept open by someone in Xen, the borderworld. A Lambda scientist gives Gordon a really nice space laser of death, and another one gives him a fancy jetpack that lets him jump far. The scientists send him on his way to Xen - the most hated part of this game. Gordon jumps through Xen, blowing up an alien spider mama's abdomen, until he makes it to the lair of the Nihilanth, the giant demon baby that wants to control Earth or something. Gordon blows up his head, and then gets offered a job by a creep known as Gman. (Ever watched Skibidi Toilet? You know who you are. And who he is - sort of.) Canon says that Gordon takes the job, but in your playthrough, you can choose to reject the job offer and get thrust into a field of Alien Grunts, defenseless against them because Gman took your weapons. [/spoiler] Like I said, it may seem standard, but back then, most PC gamers were depicted as nerds. They wanted a nerdy protagonist who needed to become the action hero, rather than pulling another Doom. Sure, System Shock did something like this, but that game had terrible sales. (Buy the System Shock remake btw.) This kind of story was revolutionary back then.

Now for the gameplay. It's pretty dang great. There are puzzles, and the combat is really well designed - you will never, EVER feel like a specific weapon is rusting. The crowbar is good for taking out really close headcrabs if you don't wanna waste ammo, and also for crushing crates - again, if you don't wanna waste ammo. The machine gun has plentiful ammo in the game's second act, and the crossbow is real nice because it is way overpowered and can shoot underwater (not to mention the scope it comes with!) However, it is really slow to shoot, and REALLY slow to reload, giving you an incentive to use the revolver aboveground - it can one-shot most enemies, but ammo's really rare. The hivehand generates its own ammo, and the gluon gun is just hilariously overpowered (but uranium 238 is quite rare). The tau cannon is really strong, but uses the same ammo as the gluon gun, which is stronger.

The game's levels are really well crafted, and they feel so tightly packed and full of secrets. (In development, Gabe Newell told the development staff to never have a dull moment in the game - if someone shoots the wall, they don't want to feel like said wall is ignoring them.) Xen really wasn't so bad - just repetitive. (Wish Half-Life Source had redesigned it with Source's better handling of outdoor areas, but hey, Black Mesa got it down.) [spoiler] The demon baby was defeated easily by me without using any energy weapons or even getting teleported anywhere. [/spoiler]

All in all - you know you have ten bucks lying around. What better use is there - Half-Life 2? Portal? Well, maybe, but still. You probably already have Portal, anyway.

Half-Life is a classic for a reason and continues to be a great entry into the long and hallowed halls of the first person shooter. Although the game may feel a bit dated today, it's still a great time that genuinely still feels fresh over 25 years later. Plus it's at an incredible price point (10$ normally, and I snagged it for 99 cents on sale) so there's not really a reason to not have played it by now.

OVERALL SCORE: 8/10

TIME VALUE: 9/10          
MONEY VALUE: 9/10          
GAMEPLAY: 9/10                  
PRESENTATION: 7/10 
MUSIC: ?/10 (will talk about later)                    
STORY: 6/10

You know what Half-Life is. You don't need me to tell you what Half-Life is. You shoot stuff, you escape the Black Mesa Foundation, and you see some pretty freaky things in the process. What you might need me to tell you is that Half-Life is still very deserving of your time, even if it's ancient.

For how old the game is, it still controls incredibly well. It's no surprise that a lot of the best modern shooters were built on Source (take both TF2s, for instance). The engine feels good, even in its early days. Everything feels incredibly responsive and fast, meaning that fighting is fun, simple as that. There's a large variety of weapons, environments, and enemies to keep you on your toes, evolving with your arsenal throughout the course of the game.

Outside of primary combat, some of the cracks begin to show. HL's movement felt very slippery to me, which  combined with platforming to lead to at least one frustrating experience. I don't think I knew how much platforming and puzzle solving there was in HL - it's not a ton, but it's definitely more than I would have thought before playing the game. There's a lot of variety, and the game definitely rewards you for paying attention to the environment and thinking outside of the box.

The level design is another highlight of HL: each stage presents it's own unique set of challenges and gimmicks. From the dingy vents and ruins of the Materials Lab to the military action on the surface, there's something new at every turn. Levels are tight, without too much stuff to sidetrack you with, although that didn't stop me from getting lost a few times. The design was strong, but there were definitely aspects that felt outdated.

Speaking of outdated, there are definitely quite a few things that will remind you that this game is 25 years old. The barebones settings, the low-poly graphics, and simplistic AI are all telltale signs of the era of this game. That's not really a fault against the game, they don't really get in the way of a good time at all, but it is something that you WILL notice. There are a lot of modern fixes to these problems, I'm sure, but I feel that the old graphics hold up quite well and the barebones settings weren't ever problematic (although they did lead to me basically turning down the music for the entire game to manage audio balance).

Something dated that was a bit more problematic was the game design. A lot of HL's game design is brilliant, setting a high bar for games to come after. Other parts of HL's game design feel like they come straight from the 90s. I could get lost and I wouldn't know if I was just being stupid or the game was just being archaic. Thankfully, it's not too hard to figure out how to fix these issues, but I would be lying if I said they weren't a problem at all. A minor nitpick, but still. These minor frustrations really stymied a lot of my enjoyment, and led to me getting really frustrated over nothing. Highlights include thinking a door was blocking a path leading to me taking about 40 minutes to try to find an alternate path before realizing I could just interact with the door. It happens.

At the end of the day, Half-Life is considered a masterpiece for a reason, and the internet doesn't need another essay about why it rocks. The game does feel old, but it also feels good. It was fun, and it had me glued to my screen. Give it a try! It's good to get back to the roots, after all.

So Half Life is now 25 years old.  The milestone motivated me to finally finish this original version for myself (I finished Black Mesa before this), and as much as I enjoyed this game, I also have some pretty mixed feelings that make me wish reviews on Steam weren't a simple yes or no.  I decided to recommend this game in the end, but this game has a LOT of flaws that are more apparent 25 years later.  Very important to note, I played on normal for this review.

For an FPS game originally released in 1998, this game was (and still is) super impressive, in both gameplay and now iconic graphics.  You acquire a pretty big arsenal throughout the game, and I did find uses for all of the weapons.  Unfortunately, the subject of combat is where my opinions start to become mixed.  It was around the fifth chapter that things started to go downhill for me, which just happens to be the chapter where the military enemies are introduced, but also other enemies introduced after.

The entire middle of the game from that point on is just the worst.  Enemies, human or alien, can take AND deal a ton of punishment, and you can't deal as much of it as you thought, which makes what initially felt like a plentiful 200 max health for you feel like you could die in about 3 seconds.  It also doesn't help that there are regular surprise moments with enemies behind corners or otherwise out of view that killed me SO MANY TIMES.  The game also becomes cheap with resources around this point, so don't be surprised if you're regularly under 10 health with not enough ammo for your good weapons and have to quick save just to get through (LOOKING AT YOU SURFACE TENSION).

On top of that, the game has a lot more moments of platforming and puzzle solving.  The puzzles can be a pain sometimes if you miss a small button or something somewhere and spend an obnoxious amount of time trying to find it, but they're usually fine as long as you're paying attention to your surroundings.  However, the platforming is AWFUL.  Gordon's speed and momentum makes it feel like he's constantly on ice.  This isn't a problem in combat situations (that speed can even be helpful), but the platforming moments definitely caused the most amount of deaths for me because of the controls being combined with constant do or die situations.

Fortunately, the game starts to pick up again near the end.  After surface tension, the puzzles and combat become more forgiving (largely due to the weapons you receive at this point, as well as having minimal military enemies and traps to deal with), resources become common enough so that you aren't constantly in critical condition, and platforming takes a MASSIVE backseat.  The last few chapters in Xen have some mild platforming, but it's actually manageable with the long jump (provided you can get the hang of it.), and the combat definitely doesn't ask for too much if you've managed to make it this far.

By the end, I enjoyed my playthrough of Half Life.  If you can get through the middle of it, the beginning and the end are great, and you can see how revolutionary this game must've been back in 1998.  However, with Black Mesa existing and being the superior version of this game, I would honestly just play that unless you want a nostalgia trip.  And if you DO want to play this version, play on easy if you don't want to rip your hair out (at least in terms of combat) during the midgame.

[h1]Half-Life: A Timeless Masterpiece that Redefined Gaming Innovation"[/h1]

Released in 1998, Half-Life stands as an enduring testament to innovation in the world of video games. Two and a half decades later, its influence remains palpable, and its gameplay, narrative, and design continue to captivate players. As a pioneer of the first-person shooter (FPS) genre, Half-Life's groundbreaking contributions have left an indelible mark on the gaming landscape.

At its core, Half-Life revolutionized storytelling in video games. Unlike its contemporaries, the game immersed players in a narrative that unfolded seamlessly within the game world. The absence of cutscenes and the use of a first-person perspective allowed for an unprecedented level of player agency, creating an immersive experience that felt more like a living, breathing world than a scripted sequence of events. The mysterious and atmospheric Black Mesa Research Facility served as the perfect backdrop for the unfolding chaos, keeping players engaged and invested in the unfolding plot.

The innovative use of scripted sequences and in-game events was a hallmark of Half-Life's design. From the iconic [spoiler]resonance cascade that sets the story in motion to the unpredictable encounters with the enigmatic G-Man[/spoiler], the game's dynamic events created a sense of unpredictability and urgency, establishing a blueprint that many subsequent titles would follow. This commitment to environmental storytelling added layers of depth and nuance, making the game's world feel rich and alive.

One of Half-Life's most enduring legacies is its introduction of the HEV suit-wearing protagonist, Gordon Freeman. Silent and unassuming, Freeman became a symbol of player immersion, as gamers projected themselves onto the scientist thrust into a nightmare. The absence of cutscenes meant that every revelation and twist occurred in real-time, heightening the emotional impact and ensuring that players were an integral part of the unfolding narrative.

Beyond its narrative innovations, Half-Life set new standards for level design and interactivity. The game featured a seamless world without loading screens, creating a sense of continuity rarely seen at the time. Puzzles were integrated into the environment, encouraging players to think critically and explore their surroundings. 

The longevity of Half-Life's influence is also evident in the modding community it spawned. Counter-Strike, Day of Defeat, and Team Fortress all originated as Half-Life mods, showcasing the game's versatility and providing a platform for creative expression that continues to this day.

In the realm of graphics and audio, Half-Life may show its age, but the art direction and sound design remain timeless. The eerie resonance of the headcrab's screech and the industrial hum of the Black Mesa facility contribute to an atmosphere that is both haunting and unforgettable.

In conclusion, Half-Life's legacy is firmly rooted in its groundbreaking innovations that not only shaped the FPS genre but also influenced the broader gaming landscape. Its commitment to player agency, environmental storytelling, and seamless world design set a standard that few games have surpassed. Whether revisiting it for a nostalgic trip down memory lane or experiencing it for the first time, Half-Life's impact is undeniable, and its status as a timeless masterpiece is well-deserved.

Overall, Half-Life is one of the greatest First Person Shooters of all time and paved the way for many beloved series today.

I played the demo of Half-Life when it was originally released. It came with cover CD-ROM of some PC gaming magazine. I had tried Doom, Quake, Unreal and Duke Nukem 3D, but Half-Life felt it had something new, something that combined all those previously mentioned games in it's own unique way. 
Later friend got the full game  (this was before Steam existed so it was released by Sierra) and we were so impressed how the story was seamlessly integrated to game play and how all the cutscenes happened inside the game engine. The game was so interesting that we played it many hours in to midnight and continued next day and the next,  probably continuing to play the game over the week, only stopping while going to school or sleeping. Btw. That was back in 1998 and we were teenagers.
Soon I discovered all the cool single player mods (They Hunger was my fave) and the famous team based online mod called "Counter Strike". Those were the days...
Later I also played the PlayStation 2 version of HL and that was it's own experience with all of it's enchantments for graphics that later found their way to Steam version, but I always felt that the original models belong to PC version. 

It's really great that Valve still shows love for the  game that made them famous. The current 25th Anniversary Edition with restored old-school look with full Steam Deck compatibility truly is the definitive edition of HL. 

My Steam game time may  not look like a lot, but I have original pre-Steam physical versions of the game for PS2 and PC so I have basically played Half-Life most of my life :D

As an avid gamer and a fan of the first-person shooter genre, I highly recommend Half-Life 1 to anyone who has not yet had the pleasure of playing this classic game. Released in 1998, Half-Life 1 set the bar for immersive storytelling, innovative gameplay mechanics, and stunning visuals in the industry.

The game follows the story of Dr. Gordon Freeman, a brilliant physicist who finds himself in the middle of a catastrophic event at the Black Mesa Research Facility. As the facility collapses around him, Freeman is forced to navigate through the ruins and uncover the truth behind the chaos. The game's captivating narrative, combined with its engaging gameplay mechanics, will keep players hooked from start to finish.

One of the most impressive aspects of Half-Life 1 is its physics engine, which was groundbreaking at the time of its release. The game's physics system allows for objects to be manipulated in a realistic and intuitive way, adding an extra layer of immersion to the gameplay. From moving crates to launching yourself off a ramp, the physics system in Half-Life 1 is both fun and satisfying.

The game's graphics, while dated by today's standards, still hold up remarkably well. The environments are detailed and atmospheric, with a variety of locations ranging from the ruins of the Black Mesa Research Facility to the depths of an underground laboratory. The game's sound design is also noteworthy, with immersive sound effects and a hauntingly memorable soundtrack.

In terms of gameplay mechanics, Half-Life 1 strikes a perfect balance between action and strategy. Players will need to use their wits and resources to overcome obstacles and enemies, with a variety of weapons and tools at their disposal. The game's enemies are also diverse and challenging, requiring players to adapt their strategies to each encounter.

In conclusion, Half-Life 1 is a must-play for anyone who loves first-person shooters or classic games. Its innovative physics engine, immersive storytelling, and engaging gameplay mechanics make it a true classic that still holds up today. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or a newcomer to the genre, Half-Life 1 is a game that you won't want to miss.

An all time favorite. If you're looking for a fast-paced twitch shooter, you're out of luck. You're a physicist who has never fired a gun in his life. Reflexes will only do you so much good without the wits to back it up. Your goal isn't to shoot everything in sight, it's to survive the worst ordeal of your life.

A pensive, methodical slow burn of a game with a brilliant yet understated narrative to boot. Don't think for a second you're in for any lulls of gameplay with ham-fisted cutscenes, spoon-fed exposition, or walls of text. Not a chance. The gameplay is the story. You are on your own.  What matters is how closely you decide to examine it.

If you love subtle and cerebral storytelling combined with clever and intense action with only your wits and reflexes to protect you, you absolutely need to get this game. Few titles out there have the care and quality this 25+ year old title has. Incredible mechanical design, phenomenal atmosphere and pacing, fantastic narrative structure and presentation, absolutely superb level design, unsurpassed cohesion, and boundless ambition went into making this an enduring classic that aged like a fine wine and combines wonderfully throughout as a single body. Highest recommendation to a game I can give.

If you've even once thought in passing this game might be good, say no more, and get it while it's on sale. Go in completely blind if you can. But enough dilly-dallying. You have a job to do.

In this game, you play as Gordon Freeman. Gordon is a wet bar of soap with a crowbar. He has the extremely common and mundane ability to carry multiple weapons in his . He can retrieve anything stored in his  with relative ease, but for some reason he stacks them together based on weapon category. You have to push the same key multiple times to reach most weapons after you find them. Weird, but lots of variety.

What's most interesting to me is how well ladders actually work in this game. I mean, it's a video game, and it's old. Yet somehow, once you figure out that looking up makes you climb up, and down for down, and walking is the best way to approach one from the top, it actually has an impressive ladder mechanic for such an old game. I'm surprised I even noticed this. On the other hand, moving on flat ground is like trying to force a cat into a wet sink. They got ladders right, but walking was too hard apparently. Still, like Super Metroid and ledge-grabbing, nobody has ever gotten ladders to work this well since. Fight me.

Maybe Black Mesa... or how Gordon Freeman changed the world - a must-have, if you're not a graphic next-gen purist.

During an experiment gone wrong, where you're the one that pushed the crystal into the analyzer, you're the only hope of the survivors to reach the search and rescue team, because of your combinaison. However, you'll have to survive from the attacks of your coworkers transformed in zombies and creatures coming from another world. And unfortunately for you, your only weapon is a crowbar. And you're just a scientist employed by Black Mesa...

That's Half-Life for you. A scientist relying on a crowbar first before becoming an expert in weapons. The story is perhaps basic and with some twists but noneless, the universe build around Half-Life has expanded a lot.

However, if Half-Life is a FPS, which means weapons to shoot any enemies, that you can carry thanks to your wonderful combinaison, you can find some puzzles throughout the game, mainly because of the need to wander around a destroyed facility.

What's fascinating in Half-Life isn't probably the gameplay in itself. I mean, everything seems very basic. But if it wasn't for it, you wouldn't have mods like Counter-Strike around. I don't know why I was fascinated by Half-Life. I mean, it's not like jumping was new or that weapons were innovative... maybe the iconic crowbar has to do something with. Or maybe it's just that a plot, perhaps basic but very effective, the mysterious G-Man following you around and disappearing easily or that the fact it's someone that wasn't trained to become the hero of the world... or maybe the ending. I don't know but I just know that when I played it, I was fascinated.

I was fascinated by the fact that you can find survivors around that can help you, guards or scientists. Or the fact that some of them meet a tragic fate under your eyes. I was fascinated by the change of the objectives: from reaching the surface, you're now the only hope to end an invasion and the wiping of any survivor by the soldiers.

I don't remember any problem with the gameplay apart the treacherous ladders. Climbing them isn't hard. However, when you needed to step out of them OR going down, it was a challenge. And the famous jumping with the crates where you were sliding...

Half-Life has the graphics from 1998 and it was very good ones. Even now, I could still enjoy them. I don't say that it's detailed. But you can see some interesting details. And Xen, the other world, despite being a challenge, is very beautiful.

Besides, the soundtrack is also great. It's only heard during some important moments. But the music is powerful.

Half-Life is a classic to have. Gordon Freeman is a character that you can't forget. And with the 25th anniversary...

Half-Life 1, the groundbreaking first-person shooter released in 1998, remains an enduring classic that has shaped the gaming landscape. Even after more than two decades, the game's brilliance is unmistakable.

From the moment players step into the shoes of Gordon Freeman, a scientist caught in a scientific disaster at the Black Mesa Research Facility, the immersive experience begins. What sets Half-Life apart is its commitment to uninterrupted gameplay; there are no cutscenes, and the narrative unfolds seamlessly through the player's perspective. This design choice, coupled with a gripping storyline and atmospheric setting, creates a sense of tension and curiosity that keeps you glued to the screen.

The gameplay is a perfect blend of exploration, puzzle-solving, and intense combat. Armed with an iconic crowbar and an array of inventive weapons, players face off against both human and extraterrestrial foes. The level design is exceptional, offering a challenging and varied experience that keeps you on your toes.

Graphically, Half-Life was a pioneer in its time. While the visuals may appear dated by today's standards, they were revolutionary in 1998, showcasing detailed environments, realistic character models, and atmospheric lighting. The game's use of the GoldSrc engine laid the foundation for future advancements in gaming technology.

Half-Life's impact goes beyond its technical achievements; it has become a cultural touchstone for gamers. The modding community has flourished around it, creating a wealth of user-generated content that adds to the game's replayability. The legacy of Half-Life is evident in the continued popularity of the franchise and its influence on subsequent generations of game developers.

In summary, Half-Life 1 is a timeless gem that deserves a place in every gamer's library. Its innovative design, gripping narrative, and pioneering technology have secured its status as a classic that continues to be enjoyed by both nostalgic veterans and a new generation of players. If you haven't experienced the origin of the Half-Life saga, it's a journey well worth taking

If you missed it the first time round, you won't have nostalgia to smooth over all the glaring wrinkles. I'd suggest playing Half-Life 2 and the Episodes instead, which are as fresh today as they were when they were released. 

It's like Mario 64- hugely important game, mind-blowing at the time... but there's no real reason to play it when Super Mario Galaxy and Odyssey are available.

[h1] (+ = Pros, - = Cons)
-------------------------------------------------------------- [/h1]
+ First FPS game to fully incorporate a Narrative-Driven story (as opposed to the industry standard of maze gallery shooters which was the Wolfenstein 3D / Doom mechanic).
- Perpetual sprint with optional walking by pressing “Shift” (as opposed to today's standard which is the reverse).
+ Excellent level designs.
+ Realistic combat mechanics (may be not as realistic now, but in 1998, it was).
- Melee weapon needs to be equipped rather than bound to a hotkey (though CS:GO players won't have a problem with this).
+ Fun puzzles.
- No objective tracker (players may forget what they were doing especially if they haven't played in a while).
+ Great sound effects.
+ First FPS game to incorporate scripted sequences for its level transitions rather than cut-scenes.
+ Relatively (and surprisingly) advanced AI (back in 1998), with enemies actively dodging, tactically retreating and often times baiting you into an ambush (literally, there is a point in the game where you get knocked out).
+ Fun fast-paced multiplayer action that set the foundations for Counter-Strike which started as a just a mere mod of Half-Life.
+ Mods; although Half-Life is not the first video game to be modded, it is the first to have several such mods become their own full games that still retain their Half-Life heritage.
+ Challenging difficulty modes (but this is a given since most old-school shooters were challenging).

[h1] Conclusion: 10/13 - "Masterpiece" [/h1]

"Half-Life" may be as important to PC gaming as what the original "Super Mario Bros." was to console gaming.  Back in 1998 this was Valve's first retail product and in November of 2023 Valve updated the game for it's 25th anniversary which added some "lost content" and updated some graphics settings, updated controller and networking support, adding official support for play on the Steam Deck, among incorporating various fixes and other content.  This version of the game, now 25 years old, is considered by Valve to be the definitive version which they say they will continue to support and update as time goes on, so it truly deserves the "Labor of Love Award".

There's a good reason why this game is getting special treatment all these years later.  "Half-Life" is more than just a mere shooter; puzzles and storytelling are equally important parts to the game.  These concepts carry throughout the whole series.  This game was instantly recognized for the high quality graphics, gameplay, and narrative.  25 years ago the sci-fi setting made this game stand out from many shooting games.  There are some really creative puzzles and unique enemies and creatures in this game.  The weapons also are cool, the script is interesting, and majority of the levels are well done.  All these years later I honestly still dread the water level, though!

Everything about this game was just different when it came out compared to traditional shooters.  Even the enemies behaved differently than they did in most other games from the same time.  I'd like to think that most of the things that were unique back then still sets it apart from shooters today.  Even if you did not get the game for free during the 25th anniversary weekend giveaway, this game frequently goes on sale for 90% off so it's definitely worth playing through to see how revolutionary this game is.

My old review does not give justice to this masterpiece of a game. Half-Life truly is one of THE games of all time. Whenever you complete Half-Life, it's like getting a Pokemon gym badge for completing this game. I say that because Half-Life is one of the major icons for gaming along with titles like Dark Souls, Metal Gear Solid, Resident Evil (Resident Evil 4 specifically), etc. Let me remind you that Half-Life was made during 1998, 25 years ago. 25 years ago, immersion in 3D video games was not able to be sold with realistic models. The time that Half-Life was made was whenever the video game models and textures were made up of about 5 or 6 polygons. So, the way that game developers would have to sell immersion in games like Half-Life or Ocarina of Time would have to be interactable and cause and effect environments, if that makes sense. Events that could happen in the world (hopefully not a resonance cascade). You never lose control and are forced to look at something except for like 2 instances. One instance where you get jumped, and a second instance at the end of the game (which I will not explain because I would like to keep the review spoiler-free). Now, Half-Life may have good immersion, but it doesn't really matter whenever you have bad gameplay. Luckily, you don't have to worry about that. Half-Life is the foundation of everything on this website: Steam. Half-Life is the foundation of Valve. I'd say it's about time to thank Valve for everything you see here and give their first ever *RELEASED* project a chance. Please, give it a shot. Enjoy the game. Don't sit here reading the whole review just to read it, and feel accomplished. You should play Half-Life, now!

Waiting to play this classic in 2023 was a terrible idea. 

Unpopular opinion incoming!!! 

Every frustrating thing was present; terrible platforming, old school terrifying ladders, instant death mechanics around some corners, unbalanced ammo (too much or too)... I don't mean to say that the game is 100% bad at all, but I'm going in my 40s and I played so many games prior to this one... It's just impossible for me to review this title kindly. Especially considering how much people always told me this was the best FPS ever.

I'm not going to do the usual Story, Gameplay, Graphics and Audio breakdown and I'll just give a short review instead.

Basically, it's a classic retro shooter with a slippery footed protagonist and deadly ladders with lots of janky jumping sections. Game had a vision, for sure, but I played it WAAAAY too late to be able to enjoy it. If you're like me and was just wondering what all the fuss was about, skip. This is no Portal or Left for Dead. I guess what I'm saying is if you just wanted to experience Half-Life to know how it was like or if it lives up to the hype and you'd never played it, well... I'll say the same thing as for the Witcher series. Don't play the first entry. Oh, that's right, there's no 3rd entry to play.... Play the second one I guess.

It's Half-Life.

[hr][/hr]
[h2][b]KLSR;[/b][/h2]
[h3][i](Kinda Long, Still Read)[/i][/h3]

It is my firm belief that 1998 was one of the single best years for gaming ever. Let's take a look at just a few of the games from that batch:
   - Baldur's Gate
   - Fallout 2
   - F-Zero X
   - Grim Fandango
   - Metal Gear Solid
   - Ocarina of Time
   - Resident Evil 2
   - StarCraft
   - Thief: The Dark Project
   - Turok 2: Seeds of Evil
[strike]Oh yeah, that year also included Sonic Adventure and Gex. Can't forget those.[/strike]

And despite that competition, Half-Life [b]STILL[/b] managed to etch its name in history as one of the most important milestones in gaming history. That alone is enough to earn the game respect, but is it still worth playing after 25 years of graphical development and modern gaming conventions? Well, let's take a look at what it still brings to the table:
   - An atmospheric setting with world-building organically built into fun-first level areas.
   - Well designed combat encounters with a variety of unique weapons (each with their own niches) that reward both caution and quick thinking.
   - A masterfully paced flow from from creeping dread to puzzle-solving/exploration to high-octane action that keeps any one part of the gameplay loop from growing stale.

That, to me, is the heart of Half-Life. Strong atmosphere infused with character every step of the way refined by iterative testing to make gameplay flow as seamlessly as possible. Despite the dated visuals, despite the lack of realist conventions found in modern shooters (HL has health packs, no ADS, walk button instead of a sprint button, etc), Half-Life still excels in all the most timeless aspects of game design. It transcends being a good 90's shooter and transcends being a good shooter; it's just a good game.

9/10.

Half-Life is a classic game. It's considered to be one of the greatest games of all time. Even though the game's visuals haven't aged well, it still has its charm. Half-Life is also a unique first-person shooter with sci-fi horror elements. Let's look into the pros and cons.

[The 25th anniversary is great and even though I have not experienced all of what's offered, I'm impressed with what Value has done for this game. I'm glad Valve still gives support to their games after all of these years.]

Pros:
• Good gameplay
• F6 & F7 are very essential and helpful
• Enjoyable set-pieces
• Pretty good sound effects
• Creative and interesting enemies and monster design
• Good storytelling in that the game speaks for itself and doesn't drown you in cutscene after cutscene, take notes game devs
• Classic characters like Gman
• Fun weapons like the Tau Cannon and Gluon Gun
• Last chapters were frustrating, but fascinating with the alien world
• Runs great

Cons:
• Platforming segments can be really irritating
• Chapters like Surface Tension can go screw itself
• Graphics have not age well

  In conclusion, even though Half-Life has its frustrating moments, the best parts of it and its pros outweigh the cons. I recommend it if you want to try a classic first-person shooter that isn't your run-of-the-mill military shooter. Also, it would be cool if Valve made a Half-Life 3.

Upon arriving late to work one summer's morn, a practitioner of scientific enlightenment was greeted with surliness from his cohorts. For today was a very special day. A day with absolutely no room for tardiness or incongruity. 

Deep within the Black Chamber of Wonderment, a magic crystal had been sent forth from a G-rand old wizard. Our hero's task was to manipulate said crystal into the Gloriously Glimmering Gizmo - which he did with earnest.

But alas, it was all a duplicitous scheme configured by that pale G-rand Wizard.

Our hero was thrown hither and thither, gazing upon beings which reside within the cosmos unknown. Then suddenly, darkness.

Awakening back in the chamber, your challenge is to guide our hero topside out of the newly wrought wreckage. Ahead of you lies peril, betrayal and a galactic menace. 

With only a pry bar at hand, will you survive?

An astonishment in electronic entertainment. Until you've frolicked with Freeman, consider your Life-Half lived!

I see a lot of people dismiss this game because of the dated graphics which is pretty silly. Yes, it doesn't hold up that great, and yes, all the audio in the game is extremely compressed, but you have to consider it came out in *1998*. This game raised the bar immensely for the FPS genre when it came out. Instead of your typical 'run and gun' games which were void of any sort of narrative, HL1 entices the player with an enriched story and complex worldbuilding. The player feels involved in the setting around them and progression depended on problem solving skills in various puzzles, not just combat skill. The dynamic enemies and the increasingly more dangerous aliens keep gameplay fresh, and the vast array of weaponry is awesome, it's only a shame the sequel lacked as much variety (but more than compensated in its characters, puzzles, and story).

Overall a very good game and not just the best game of the 1990s, but possibly the best FPS to date.
